å¦å¤–ï¼Œè¡¨æ²¡æœ‰åŒ…å«æ ‡é¢˜ã€‚

import pandas as pd # ä»æ²¡æœ‰æ ‡é¢˜çš„CSVæ–‡ä»¶ä¸­è¯»å–IDåˆ—è¡¨ csv_file_path = 'C:/Users/a/Desktop/IlluminaèŠ¯ç‰‡åˆ†æè¡¨.csv' df_no_header = pd.read_csv(csv_file_path, header=None) # åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªé›†åˆï¼ŒåŒ…å«æ‰€æœ‰çš„ID id_set = set(df_no_header[0]) # å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ›´ä¸¥æ ¼çš„é€»è¾‘ä»FASTAæ–‡ä»¶ä¸­æå–åºåˆ— def read_and_extract_fasta_strict(fasta_path, ids): with open(fasta_path, "r") as fasta_file: lines = fasta_file.readlines() extract = False extracted_sequences = [] current_sequence = [] # éå†æ¯ä¸€è¡Œ for line in lines: if line.startswith(">"): line_id = line.split()[0][1:] # æå–è¡Œä¸­çš„ID if line_id in ids: extract = True if current_sequence: extracted_sequences.append("".join(current_sequence)) current_sequence = [] # ä¿æŒåŸå§‹IDä¸å˜ updated_id = f">{line_id}\n" current_sequence.append(updated_id) else: if extract: extracted_sequences.append("".join(current_sequence)) current_sequence = [] extract = False else: if extract: current_sequence.append(line) if current_sequence: extracted_sequences.append("".join(current_sequence)) return extracted_sequences # FASTAæ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„å’Œæ–°FASTAæ–‡ä»¶ä¿å­˜è·¯å¾„ fasta_file_path = 'C:/Users/a/Desktop/Illumina_mtDNA_Filter_recode.fasta' new_fasta_file_path = 'C:/Users/a/Desktop/extracted_sequences.fasta' # ä½¿ç”¨ä¿®æ­£åçš„å‡½æ•°ä»FASTAæ–‡ä»¶ä¸­æå–åºåˆ— extracted_sequences_strict = read_and_extract_fasta_strict(fasta_file_path, id_set) # å°†æå–çš„åºåˆ—ä¿å­˜åˆ°æ–°çš„FASTAæ–‡ä»¶ with open(new_fasta_file_path, "w") as output_fasta: for sequence in extracted_sequences_strict: output_fasta.write(sequence) # è¾“å‡ºæ–°FASTAæ–‡ä»¶çš„è·¯å¾„ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºä»»åŠ¡å®Œæˆ print(f"æå–çš„åºåˆ—å·²ä¿å­˜è‡³: {new_fasta_file_path}") å¤åˆ¶

item.title: ä½œç”¨
item.description:
è¯¥è„šæœ¬çš„ä½œç”¨æ˜¯ï¼Œæ ¹æ®åŸå§‹çš„è¡¨æ ¼è®¡ç®—åœ¨æŸç§æ²¡ç±»çŠ¶æ€ä¸‹çš„å•å€ç¾¤é¢‘ç‡ï¼Œå¹¶æŒ‰ç…§å­—ç¬¦é•¿åº¦è‡ªåŠ¨ç”Ÿæˆæ‰€æœ‰çº§åˆ«çš„å•å€ç¾¤ï¼Œç„¶ååˆ©ç”¨ç´¯åŠ åŸåˆ™ï¼ˆä¸Šæ¸¸å•å€ç¾¤=ä¸‹æ¸¸å•å€ç¾¤ä¹‹å’Œï¼‰è¿›è¡Œç´¯åŠ ã€‚


ç¬¬ä¸€åˆ—å¯ä»¥ä¸è¦ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯éœ€è¦æœ‰ Haplotype åˆ—å’Œ Classficationã€‚

import pandas as pd import os # è¯»å–åŸå§‹æ•°æ® file_path = 'C:/Users/victo/Desktop/å—åŒ—æ–¹åŸå§‹æ•°æ®.csv' # è¯·æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºä½ çš„æ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„ data = pd.read_csv(file_path) # è®¡ç®—æ¯ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸå†…çš„æ¯ä¸ªHaplotypeçš„æ•°é‡ haplogroup_counts = data.groupby(['Haplotype', 'Classfication']).size().reset_index(name='count') # åˆ›å»ºæ•°æ®é€è§†è¡¨ï¼Œå°†Haplotypeä½œä¸ºè¡Œï¼ŒåŒºåŸŸä½œä¸ºåˆ— haplogroup_pivot = haplogroup_counts.pivot(index='Haplotype', columns='Classfication', values='count').fillna(0) # è®¡ç®—æ¯ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸå†…æ¯ä¸ªHaplotypeçš„é¢‘ç‡ haplogroup_pivot = haplogroup_pivot.div(haplogroup_pivot.sum(axis=0), axis=1) * 100 # æå–Haplotypeåˆ—è¡¨å¹¶å¤„ç† haplogroups = data['Haplotype'].tolist() processed_haplogroups = [] # æŒ‰è§„åˆ™å¤„ç†Haplotype for haplogroup in haplogroups: processed_haplogroups.append(haplogroup) while len(haplogroup) > 1: haplogroup = haplogroup[:-1] processed_haplogroups.append(haplogroup) # å»é‡å¹¶æ’åº unique_processed_haplogroups = sorted(set(processed_haplogroups)) # åˆ›å»ºåŒ…å«å¤„ç†åHaplotypeçš„æ–°DataFrame final_df = pd.DataFrame(unique_processed_haplogroups, columns=['Haplotype']) # åˆå¹¶æœ€ç»ˆDataFrameå’ŒHaplotypeé¢‘ç‡DataFrame proce_df = final_df.merge(haplogroup_pivot, how='left', left_on='Haplotype', right_index=True).fillna(0) # å°†ç»“æœä¿å­˜åˆ°CSVæ–‡ä»¶ proce_df.to_csv('./PROCE.csv', index=False) df_cleaned = pd.read_csv('./PROCE.csv') # å°†é¢‘ç‡åˆ—è½¬æ¢ä¸ºæ•°å€¼ç±»å‹ df_cleaned.iloc[:, 1:] = df_cleaned.iloc[:, 1:].apply(pd.to_numeric, errors='coerce').fillna(0) # è·å–Haplotypeåˆ—è¡¨ haplogroups = df_cleaned['Haplotype'].tolist() # åˆå§‹åŒ–ç´¯åŠ é¢‘ç‡å­—å…¸ cumulative_freq = {col: {hg: 0 for hg in haplogroups} for col in df_cleaned.columns[1:]} # å®šä¹‰æ£€æŸ¥Haplotypeæ˜¯å¦æ˜¯å¦ä¸€ä¸ªHaplotypeä¸‹çº§çš„å‡½æ•° def is_descendant(parent, child): return child.startswith(parent) and len(child) > len(parent) # å‡è®¾ is_descendant å‡½æ•°å’Œ haplogroups, df_cleaned, cumulative_freq æ•°æ®æ¡†å·²å®šä¹‰ # ç¼“å­˜ is_descendant ç»“æœ descendant_cache = {} for parent in haplogroups: # å…ˆå¤„ç† parent è‡ªèº«çš„æ•°æ® for col in df_cleaned.columns[1:]: if not df_cleaned.loc[df_cleaned['Haplotype'] == parent, col].empty: cumulative_freq[col][parent] += df_cleaned.loc[df_cleaned['Haplotype'] == parent, col].values[0] for child in haplogroups: if (parent, child) not in descendant_cache: descendant_cache[(parent, child)] = is_descendant(parent, child) if descendant_cache[(parent, child)]: for col in df_cleaned.columns[1:]: if not df_cleaned.loc[df_cleaned['Haplotype'] == child, col].empty: cumulative_freq[col][parent] += df_cleaned.loc[df_cleaned['Haplotype'] == child, col].values[0] # åˆ›å»ºå­˜å‚¨ç´¯åŠ é¢‘ç‡çš„æ–°DataFrame cumulative_df = pd.DataFrame(cumulative_freq).reset_index() cumulative_df.rename(columns={'index': 'Haplotype'}, inplace=True) # ä¿å­˜ç´¯åŠ é¢‘ç‡åˆ°æ–°æ–‡ä»¶ cumulative_file_path = 'C:/Users/victo/Desktop/å„çº§Haplotypeé¢‘ç‡æ€»è¡¨ç´¯è®¡.csv' cumulative_df.to_csv(cumulative_file_path, index=False) # åˆ é™¤PROCE.csv os.remove('./PROCE.csv') print("ä¸€ä¸ªä¸éœ€è¦çš„æ–‡ä»¶å·²ç»è¢«åˆ é™¤äº†;\nç´¯åŠ åçš„æ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„ï¼š", cumulative_file_path) å¤åˆ¶

# Re-importing the necessary library as the code execution state has been reset. import pandas as pd # æ›¿æ¢è¿™ä¸ªtxtæ–‡ä»¶ file_path = 'C:/Users/a/Desktop/åˆ†ç»„.txt' # Read the file into a pandas DataFrame group_data = pd.read_csv(file_path, sep="\t", header=None, names=["ID", "Category"]) # Group the IDs by category grouped = group_data.groupby('Category')['ID'].apply(list).to_dict() # Start writing the content for the .arp file arp_content = "[[Structure]]\n\n" arp_content += 'StructureName="New Edited Structure"\n' arp_content += f'NbGroups={len(grouped)}\n\n' # Loop through each category and add its IDs to the content for category, IDs in grouped.items(): arp_content += f'Group={{\n' for ID in IDs: arp_content += f'\t"{ID}"\n' arp_content += "}\n.......\n" # æ›¿æ¢è¾“å‡ºçš„æ–‡ä»¶ arp_file_path = 'C:/Users/a/Desktop/åˆ†ç»„.arp' # Write the content to the new .arp file with open(arp_file_path, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as arp_file: arp_file.write(arp_content) arp_file_path å¤åˆ¶

import pandas as pd from Bio import SeqIO def add_haplogroup_to_fasta(fasta_file, csv_file, output_file): # è¯»å–CSVæ–‡ä»¶åˆ°DataFrame haplogroups = pd.read_csv(csv_file) # åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªå­—å…¸æ¥æ˜ å°„Sample_IDåˆ°Haplogroup haplogroup_dict = dict(zip(haplogroups['Sample_ID'], haplogroups['Haplogroup'])) # è¯»å–fastaæ–‡ä»¶ with open(fasta_file, 'r') as fasta: records = list(SeqIO.parse(fasta, 'fasta')) # æ›´æ–°è®°å½•çš„ID updated_records = [] for record in records: id = record.id # æŸ¥æ‰¾å•å€ç¾¤ï¼Œå¦‚æœå­˜åœ¨åˆ™æ›´æ–°ID haplogroup = haplogroup_dict.get(id) if haplogroup: record.id = id + '_' + haplogroup # ä¿®æ”¹æ­¤å¤„æ¥è°ƒæ•´IDçš„æ ¼å¼ record.description = id + '_' + haplogroup # é€šå¸¸ä¹Ÿéœ€è¦æ›´æ–°description updated_records.append(record) # å°†æ›´æ–°åçš„fastaè®°å½•å†™å…¥æ–°æ–‡ä»¶ with open(output_file, 'w') as output: SeqIO.write(updated_records, output, 'fasta') # ä½¿ç”¨ç¤ºä¾‹ add_haplogroup_to_fasta('path_to_your_fasta_file.fasta', 'path_to_your_csv_file.csv', 'output_fasta_file.fasta') å¤åˆ¶

import os from Bio import SeqIO # Paths to the files input_txt_path = r"C:/Users/victo/Desktop/æ–°å»º Text Document.txt" input_fasta_path = r"C:/Users/victo/Desktop/10K_WMG_REFERENCE.ALN.fasta" output_fasta_path = r"C:/Users/victo/Desktop/æå–åºåˆ—.fasta" # Read the sample IDs and haplogroups from the input TXT file sample_info = {} with open(input_txt_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as txt_file: # Skip the header next(txt_file) for line in txt_file: parts = line.strip().split('\t') if len(parts) == 2: sample_id, haplogroup = parts sample_info[sample_id] = haplogroup # Ask the user if they want to include haplogroup information include_haplogroup = input("æ˜¯å¦éœ€è¦æ·»åŠ å•å€ç¾¤ä¿¡æ¯è‡³IDï¼Ÿè¯·è¾“å…¥YESæˆ–è€…NO: ").strip().upper() == 'YES' # Read the sequences from the input FASTA file and write the required sequences to the output FASTA file with open(output_fasta_path, 'w') as output_fasta: for record in SeqIO.parse(input_fasta_path, "fasta"): original_id = record.id if original_id in sample_info: if include_haplogroup: new_id = f"{original_id}_{sample_info[original_id]}" record.id = new_id record.description = new_id SeqIO.write(record, output_fasta, "fasta") print(f"æå–å·²ç»å®Œæˆ. åºåˆ—å·²ç»ä¿å­˜è‡³ï¼š{output_fasta_path}") å¤åˆ¶

# ä½¿ç”¨ä¿®æ­£åçš„å‡½æ•°ä»FASTAæ–‡ä»¶ä¸­æå–åºåˆ— extracted_sequences_strict = read_and_extract_fasta_strict(origin_fasta_file_path, id_set) # å°†æå–çš„åºåˆ—ä¿å­˜åˆ°æ–°çš„FASTAæ–‡ä»¶ with open(extracted_sequence_fasta_file_path, "w") as output_fasta: for sequence in extracted_sequences_strict: output_fasta.write(sequence) # è¾“å‡ºæ–°FASTAæ–‡ä»¶çš„è·¯å¾„ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºä»»åŠ¡å®Œæˆ print(f"æå–çš„åºåˆ—å·²ä¿å­˜è‡³: {extracted_sequence_fasta_file_path}") ############################################## ###########ç°åœ¨å¼€å§‹è¿›è¡Œfastaåºåˆ—è½¬åŒ–############ ä»¥ä¸‹ä»£ç è¯·å‹¿æ›´æ”¹æ–‡ä»¶åç§°ï¼Œè·¯å¾„è®¾ç½®ä¸ºåˆšæ‰çš„è·¯å¾„ï¼ˆå»ºè®®è®¾ç½®ä¸ºæ¡Œé¢ï¼‰ import pandas as pd # ç¤ºä¾‹è°ƒç”¨ fasta_file_path = new_fasta_file_path # è¯·å‹¿ä¿®æ”¹ï¼don't change this! group_file_path = new_csv_file_path # è¯·å‹¿ä¿®æ”¹ï¼don't change this! new_csv_path_final = './grouped_names_final.csv' # è¯·å‹¿ä¿®æ”¹ï¼don't change this! def read_fasta_file(fasta_file_path): samples = {} with open(fasta_file_path, 'r') as fasta: for line in fasta: if line.startswith('>'): current_sample = line.strip().lstrip('>') samples[current_sample] = '' else: samples[current_sample] += line.strip() return samples def create_nex_file(samples, nex_file_path): ntax = len(samples) nchar = len(next(iter(samples.values()))) if ntax > 0 else 0 nex_content = [ "#NEXUS\n\n", "Begin Data;\n", f"\tDimensions ntax={ntax} NCHAR={nchar};\n", "\tFormat datatype=DNA missing=N GAP=-;\n", "\tMATRIX\n" ] for sample_id, sequence in samples.items(): nex_content.append(f"\t{sample_id}\n{sequence}\n") nex_content.append(";\nEND;\n\n\n") with open(nex_file_path, 'w') as nex_file: nex_file.writelines(nex_content) def process_group_file_to_csv(file_path, new_csv_path_final): data = pd.read_csv(file_path, sep=',', header=None, names=['Name', 'Group'], encoding='utf-8') unique_groups_sorted = sorted(data['Group'].unique()) matrix_df = pd.DataFrame(0, index=data['Name'], columns=unique_groups_sorted) for index, row in data.iterrows(): matrix_df.at[row['Name'], row['Group']] = 1 matrix_df.reset_index(inplace=True) matrix_df.rename(columns={'index': ''}, inplace=True) matrix_df.to_csv(new_csv_path_final, index=False) def append_traits_to_nex(input_csv, nex_file_path): df = pd.read_csv(input_csv) new_columns = [col.replace(',', ' ') for col in df.columns if col != 'Name'] ntraits = len(new_columns) trait_labels = ' '.join(new_columns) nex_content = f"""Begin Traits; Dimensions NTraits={ntraits}; Format labels=yes missing=? separator=Comma; TraitLabels {trait_labels}; Matrix \n """ for index, row in df.iterrows(): row_data = ','.join([str(row[df.columns[1]])] + [str(row[col]) for col in df.columns[2:]]) nex_content += f"{row['Name']} {row_data}\n" with open(nex_file_path, 'a') as file: file.write(nex_content) file.write("\t;\n\tend;\n") samples = read_fasta_file(fasta_file_path) create_nex_file(samples, nex_file_path) process_group_file_to_csv(group_file_path, new_csv_path_final) append_traits_to_nex(new_csv_path_final, nex_file_path) # è¾“å‡ºæ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„ä»¥ä¾¿ä¸‹è½½ print(nex_file_path) # åˆ é™¤æ–°åˆ†ç±»æ±‡æ€».csv import os os.remove(new_csv_path_final) os.remove(group_file_path) print("å¤šä½™æ–‡ä»¶å·²åˆ é™¤ã€‚") å¤åˆ¶

import pandas as pd import geopandas as gpd import folium from folium.features import GeoJson, GeoJsonTooltip # åŠ è½½æ•°æ® file_path = 'C:/Users/victo/Desktop/æ•°æ®æ¸…æ´—æ•´ç†.csv' data = pd.read_csv(file_path) # è¿‡æ»¤æŒ‡å®šå•å€ç¾¤å¹¶ç»Ÿè®¡å„çœæ•°é‡ def count_haplogroup_by_province(haplogroup_name, data): filtered_data = data[data['Haplogroup'] == haplogroup_name] province_counts = filtered_data['Province'].value_counts().reset_index() province_counts.columns = ['Province', 'Count'] return province_counts # è®¡ç®—å„çœçš„å•å€ç¾¤é¢‘ç‡ def calculate_frequency(data, haplogroup_name): total_counts = data['Province'].value_counts().reset_index() total_counts.columns = ['Province', 'Total'] haplogroup_counts = count_haplogroup_by_province(haplogroup_name, data) frequency = pd.merge(haplogroup_counts, total_counts, on='Province') frequency['Frequency'] = frequency['Count'] / frequency['Total'] return frequency[['Province', 'Frequency']] # è·å–å•å€ç¾¤ M9a1b1c åœ¨å„çœçš„é¢‘ç‡ haplogroup_name = 'M9a1b1c' province_frequency = calculate_frequency(data, haplogroup_name) # åŠ è½½ä¸­å›½çœä»½åœ°ç†æ•°æ® china_map = gpd.read_file('C:/Users/victo/Desktop/çœé¢.shp') # æ£€æŸ¥åˆ—å print(china_map.columns) # ç¡®è®¤åœ°ç†æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„çœä»½åç§°åˆ— province_column = 'çœå…¨å' # æ ¹æ®å®é™…æƒ…å†µè°ƒæ•´åˆ—å # åˆå¹¶ç»Ÿè®¡æ•°æ®å’Œåœ°ç†æ•°æ® china_map = china_map.merge(province_frequency, left_on=province_column, right_on='Province', how='left').fillna(0) # åˆ›å»º folium åœ°å›¾ m = folium.Map(location=[35.8617, 104.1954], zoom_start=4) # æ·»åŠ  GeoJson æ•°æ® folium.Choropleth( geo_data=china_map, name='choropleth', data=china_map, columns=[province_column, 'Frequency'], key_on=f'feature.properties.{province_column}', fill_color='YlOrRd', fill_opacity=0.7, line_opacity=0.2, legend_name=f'Haplogroup {haplogroup_name} Frequency by Province' ).add_to(m) # æ·»åŠ å·¥å…·æç¤º folium.GeoJson( china_map, style_function=lambda x: {'fillColor': '#ffffff00', 'color': 'black', 'weight': 1}, tooltip=GeoJsonTooltip( fields=[province_column, 'Frequency'], aliases=['Province: ', 'Frequency: '], localize=True ) ).add_to(m) # ä¿å­˜åœ°å›¾ m.save('haplogroup_distribution_map.html') # æ‰“å° M9a1b1c å•å€ç¾¤åœ¨å„çœçš„é¢‘ç‡ print(province_frequency) å¤åˆ¶

import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import geopandas as gpd from pypinyin import pinyin, Style # åŠ è½½æ•°æ® file_path = 'C:/Users/victo/Desktop/æ•°æ®æ¸…æ´—æ•´ç†.csv' data = pd.read_csv(file_path) # è¿‡æ»¤æŒ‡å®šå•å€ç¾¤å¹¶ç»Ÿè®¡å„çœæ•°é‡ def count_haplogroup_by_province(haplogroup_name, data): filtered_data = data[data['Haplogroup'] == haplogroup_name] province_counts = filtered_data['Province'].value_counts().reset_index() province_counts.columns = ['Province', 'Count'] return province_counts # è·å–å•å€ç¾¤åœ¨å„çœçš„æ•°é‡ haplogroup_name = 'Z' province_counts = count_haplogroup_by_province(haplogroup_name, data) # è®¡ç®—å…¨å›½B5a1cçš„æ€»æ•°é‡ total_haplogroup_count = province_counts['Count'].sum() # è®¡ç®—å„çœçš„B5a1cé¢‘ç‡ province_counts['Frequency'] = province_counts['Count'] / total_haplogroup_count # å°†ä¸­æ–‡çœä»½åç§°è½¬æ¢ä¸ºæ‹¼éŸ³ province_counts['Province_pinyin'] = province_counts['Province'].apply(lambda x: ''.join([item[0] for item in pinyin(x, style=Style.NORMAL)])) # åŠ è½½ä¸­å›½çœä»½åœ°ç†æ•°æ® china_map = gpd.read_file('C:/Users/victo/Desktop/çœé¢.shp') # ç¡®è®¤åœ°ç†æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„çœä»½åç§°åˆ— province_column = 'çœå…¨å' # å°†åœ°ç†æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„çœä»½åç§°è½¬æ¢ä¸ºæ‹¼éŸ³ china_map['Province_pinyin'] = china_map[province_column].apply(lambda x: ''.join([item[0] for item in pinyin(x, style=Style.NORMAL)])) # åˆå¹¶ç»Ÿè®¡æ•°æ®å’Œåœ°ç†æ•°æ® china_map = china_map.merge(province_counts, left_on='Province_pinyin', right_on='Province_pinyin', how='left') china_map = china_map.infer_objects() # ç¡®ä¿æ•°æ®ç±»å‹æ­£ç¡® china_map = china_map.fillna(0) # å¡«å……ç¼ºå¤±å€¼ # æ£€æŸ¥province_countsæ˜¯å¦ä¸ºç©º if province_counts.empty: print("Error: The haplogroup data is empty. Please check the input data and haplogroup name.") else: # è·å–é¢‘ç‡çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼å’Œæœ€å°å€¼ max_frequency = province_counts['Frequency'].max() min_frequency = province_counts['Frequency'].min() # ç»˜åˆ¶çƒ­å›¾ fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(10, 18)) # è°ƒæ•´å›¾å½¢é«˜åº¦ china_map.boundary.plot(ax=ax, linewidth=0.03, color='#8B8B8B') china_map.plot(column='Frequency', ax=ax, legend=True, cmap='Spectral_r', # ä½¿ç”¨é…è‰² legend_kwds={'label': f"Haplogroup {haplogroup_name} Frequency by Province", 'orientation': "vertical"}, vmin=min_frequency, vmax=max_frequency) # è®¾ç½®é¢œè‰²æ¡èŒƒå›´ # éšè—åœ°å›¾å¤–æ¡†çš„æ¨ªè½´ã€çºµè½´çš„æ•°å­—æ ‡å°º ax.set_xticks([]) ax.set_yticks([]) plt.title(f'Distribution of Haplogroup {haplogroup_name} in China by Province') # æ·»åŠ è¡¨æ ¼ table_data = province_counts[['Province_pinyin', 'Count', 'Frequency']].values column_labels = ['Province', 'Count', 'Frequency'] table = plt.table(cellText=table_data, colLabels=column_labels, cellLoc='center', loc='bottom', bbox=[0, -1.4, 1, 1.2]) # è°ƒæ•´è¡¨æ ¼ä½ç½®å’Œå¤§å° table.auto_set_font_size(False) table.set_fontsize(8) # è°ƒæ•´å­—ä½“å¤§å° # è°ƒæ•´å•å…ƒæ ¼çš„é«˜åº¦ cell_dict = table.get_celld() for i in range(len(table_data) + 1): # åŒ…æ‹¬æ ‡é¢˜è¡Œ for j in range(len(column_labels)): cell_dict[(i, j)].set_height(0.15) # è°ƒæ•´å•å…ƒæ ¼é«˜åº¦ plt.subplots_adjust(left=0.2, bottom=0.4) # è°ƒæ•´å›¾å½¢å¸ƒå±€ plt.show() å¤åˆ¶

from Bio import Entrez, SeqIO # è®¾ç½®æ‚¨çš„é‚®ç®±åœ°å€ Entrez.email = "your_email@example.com" # æŒ‡å®šä¿å­˜æ–‡ä»¶çš„ç›®å½• save_directory = r"C:/Users/a/Desktop/ä¸‹è½½åºåˆ—" # å®šä¹‰å‡½æ•°ä»¥ä¸‹è½½åºåˆ—å¹¶æå–ç‰¹å¾ä¿¡æ¯ def download_and_process_sequences(id_list): for seq_id in id_list: # ä¸‹è½½fastaåºåˆ— handle_fasta = Entrez.efetch(db="nucleotide", id=seq_id, rettype="fasta", retmode="text") record_fasta = SeqIO.read(handle_fasta, "fasta") handle_fasta.close() # ä¿å­˜fastaæ–‡ä»¶ filename_fasta = f"{save_directory}\\{seq_id}.fasta" SeqIO.write(record_fasta, filename_fasta, "fasta") print(f"Downloaded and saved {filename_fasta}") # ä¸‹è½½genbankè®°å½•ä»¥æå–ç‰¹å¾ä¿¡æ¯ handle_gb = Entrez.efetch(db="nucleotide", id=seq_id, rettype="gb", retmode="text") record_gb = SeqIO.read(handle_gb, "genbank") country = isolate = lat_lon = "Not Available" for feature in record_gb.features: if feature.type == "source": qualifiers = feature.qualifiers country = qualifiers.get("country", ["Not Available"])[0] isolate = qualifiers.get("isolate", ["Not Available"])[0] lat_lon = qualifiers.get("lat_lon", ["Not Available"])[0] break reference_titles = ", ".join([ref.title for ref in record_gb.annotations.get("references", []) if ref.title]) with open(f"{save_directory}/ä¿¡æ¯.txt", "a") as output_file: output_file.write(f"{seq_id}\t{country}\t{isolate}\t{lat_lon}\t{reference_titles}\n") print(f"{seq_id}\tä¿¡æ¯å·²ç»æ‰“å°ï¼") handle_gb.close() # ä»åŒä¸€ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶è¯»å–åºåˆ—ID id_list = [] with open("C:/Users/a/Desktop/æµ‹è¯•.txt", "r") as file: for line in file: id_list.append(line.strip()) # è°ƒç”¨å‡½æ•° download_and_process_sequences(id_list) å¤åˆ¶

from sklearn.ç®—æ³•ä½ç½® import ç®—æ³•åå­— from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score # ç”¨ç²¾ç¡®åº¦è¯„ä¼°æ¨¡å‹ # ç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹å¯¹è±¡ æ¨¡å‹å = ç®—æ³•åå­—(æ¨¡å‹å‚æ•°é€‰å¡«) # è®­ç»ƒ æ¨¡å‹å.fit(train_x,train_y) scores1=cross_val_score(æ¨¡å‹å,train_x,train_y,cv=n,scoring='accuracy') # è¾“å‡ºç²¾ç¡®åº¦çš„å¹³å‡å€¼ print("åœ¨è®­ç»ƒé›†çš„ç²¾ç¡®åº¦ä¸º:{}".format(scores1.mean())) scores2=cross_val_score(æ¨¡å‹å,train_x,train_y,cv=n,scoring='accuracy') # è¾“å‡ºç²¾ç¡®åº¦çš„å¹³å‡å€¼ print("åœ¨è®­ç»ƒé›†çš„ç²¾ç¡®åº¦ä¸º:{}".format(scores2.mean())) # è¾“å‡ºç²¾ç¡®åº¦çš„å¹³å‡å€¼ # print("è®­ç»ƒé›†ä¸Šçš„ç²¾ç¡®åº¦: %0.2f " % scores1.mean()) # è¾“å‡ºç²¾ç¡®åº¦çš„å¹³å‡å€¼å’Œç½®ä¿¡åº¦åŒºé—´ print("è®­ç»ƒé›†ä¸Šçš„å¹³å‡ç²¾ç¡®åº¦: %0.2f (+/- %0.2f)" % (scores2.mean(), scores2.std() * 2)) å¤åˆ¶

###1ã€svmåˆ†ç±»å™¨ from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score,GridSearchCV from sklearn.svm import SVC svm_model = SVC() params = [ {'kernel': ['linear'], 'C': [1, 10, 100, 100]}, {'kernel': ['poly'], 'C': [1], 'degree': [2, 3]}, {'kernel': ['rbf'], 'C': [1, 10, 100, 100], 'gamma':[1, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001]} ] best_model = GridSearchCV(svm_model, param_grid=params,cv = 5,scoring = 'accuracy') best_model.fit(train_x,train_y) # æŸ¥çœ‹æœ€ä¼˜ç§€ best_model.best_score_ # æŸ¥çœ‹æœ€ä¼˜å‚æ•° best_model.best_params_ # æŸ¥çœ‹æœ€ä¼˜æ¨¡å‹çš„æ‰€æœ‰å‚æ•° best_model.best_estimator_ # æŸ¥çœ‹æ¯ä¸ªå‚æ•°çš„äº¤å‰éªŒè¯ç»“æœ best_model.cv_results_ å¤åˆ¶

item.title: æ•°æ®å‡†å¤‡
item.description:
é¥¼å›¾ååº”çš„æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ•´ä½“å†…éƒ¨å„æˆåˆ†çš„æ¯”ä¾‹ã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸€åˆ—æ˜¯æˆåˆ†ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒåˆ—æ˜¯ç±»åˆ«ã€‚


import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import matplotlib.colors as mcolors from matplotlib import rcParams # Load the dataset file_path = '10Kæ•°æ®é›†.csv' data = pd.read_csv(file_path) # Filter the data for Macro == 'M' filtered_data = data[data['Macro'] == 'N'] # Count the occurrences of each Haplogroup haplogroup_counts = filtered_data['Haplogroup'].value_counts() # Get the top 50 Haplogroups top_50_haplogroups = haplogroup_counts.head(50) # Sum the counts of the remaining Haplogroups other_count = haplogroup_counts[50:].sum() # Prepare data for pie chart pie_data = pd.concat([top_50_haplogroups, pd.Series({'Other': other_count})]) # Calculate the total number of Haplogroup 'M' total_m_count = filtered_data.shape[0] # Create a natural gradient of colors between the specified SCI colors def create_color_gradient(start_color, mid_color1, mid_color2, end_color, n): gradient_colors = np.linspace(mcolors.hex2color(start_color), mcolors.hex2color(mid_color1), n//3) gradient_colors = np.vstack((gradient_colors, np.linspace(mcolors.hex2color(mid_color1), mcolors.hex2color(mid_color2), n//3))) gradient_colors = np.vstack((gradient_colors, np.linspace(mcolors.hex2color(mid_color2), mcolors.hex2color(end_color), n - 2*(n//3)))) return [mcolors.rgb2hex(c) for c in gradient_colors] # Generate the gradient color palette # gradient_colors = create_color_gradient('#440054', '#414F8C', '#2C8D8E', '#FDE724', len(pie_data)) gradient_colors = create_color_gradient('#090387','#9611A1','#DD5E66','#FDE724', len(pie_data)) # Set font to vector font rcParams['pdf.fonttype'] = 42 rcParams['ps.fonttype'] = 42 # Plotting the pie chart with the gradient colors fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 8)) wedges, texts = ax.pie(pie_data, labels=None, colors=gradient_colors, startangle=140) # Adding legend ax.legend(pie_data.index, title="Haplogroups", loc="center left", bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0.5)) plt.title(f'Top 50 Haplogroups in Macro M ({total_m_count})') # Save the plot as an SVG file with editable text plt.savefig('C:/Users/victo/Desktop/haplogroup_pie_chart.svg', format='svg') plt.show() å¤åˆ¶

import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import matplotlib.colors as mcolors from matplotlib import rcParams # Load the dataset file_path = '10Kæ•°æ®é›†.csv' data = pd.read_csv(file_path) # Filter the data for Macro == 'M' filtered_data = data[data['Macro'] == 'M'] # Count the occurrences of each Haplogroup haplogroup_counts = filtered_data['Haplogroup'].value_counts() # Get the top 50 Haplogroups top_50_haplogroups = haplogroup_counts.head(50) # Remove 'Other' category bar_data = top_50_haplogroups # Calculate the total number of Haplogroup 'M' total_m_count = filtered_data.shape[0] # Create a natural gradient of colors between the specified SCI colors def create_color_gradient(start_color, mid_color1, mid_color2, end_color, n): gradient_colors = np.linspace(mcolors.hex2color(start_color), mcolors.hex2color(mid_color1), n//3) gradient_colors = np.vstack((gradient_colors, np.linspace(mcolors.hex2color(mid_color1), mcolors.hex2color(mid_color2), n//3))) gradient_colors = np.vstack((gradient_colors, np.linspace(mcolors.hex2color(mid_color2), mcolors.hex2color(end_color), n - 2*(n//3)))) return [mcolors.rgb2hex(c) for c in gradient_colors] # Generate the gradient color palette gradient_colors = create_color_gradient('#440054', '#414F8C', '#2C8D8E', '#FDE724', len(bar_data)) # Set font to vector font rcParams['pdf.fonttype'] = 42 rcParams['ps.fonttype'] = 42 # Plotting the bar chart with the gradient colors plt.figure(figsize=(14, 7)) bars = plt.bar(bar_data.index, bar_data.values, color=gradient_colors) # Adding title and labels plt.xlabel('Haplogroup') plt.ylabel('Count') plt.title(f'Top 50 Haplogroups in Macro M ({total_m_count})') plt.xticks(rotation=90) # Save the plot as an SVG file with editable text plt.tight_layout() plt.savefig('C:/Users/victo/Desktop/haplogroup_bar_chart.svg', format='svg') plt.show() å¤åˆ¶

item.title: COLLAPSE åŒ…
item.description:
COLLAPSE template are used to collapse branches. COLLAPSE æ¨¡æ¿ç”¨äºæŠ˜å åˆ†æ”¯ã€‚
Typically, The user merges branches A and B by folding them at their most recent common ancestor (MRCA). However, it is normally hard for users to declare the MRCA node directly. The node name is usually generated automatically by software rather than specified by the user when building the phylogenetic tree. Some programs do not even generate the node name.
é€šå¸¸ï¼Œç”¨æˆ·é€šè¿‡åœ¨æœ€è¿‘çš„å…±åŒç¥–å…ˆ (MRCA) å¤„æŠ˜å åˆ†æ”¯ A å’Œ B æ¥åˆå¹¶å®ƒä»¬ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œç”¨æˆ·é€šå¸¸å¾ˆéš¾ç›´æ¥å£°æ˜MRCAèŠ‚ç‚¹ã€‚èŠ‚ç‚¹åç§°é€šå¸¸ç”±è½¯ä»¶è‡ªåŠ¨ç”Ÿæˆï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ç”±ç”¨æˆ·åœ¨æ„å»ºç³»ç»Ÿå‘è‚²æ ‘æ—¶æŒ‡å®šã€‚æœ‰äº›ç¨‹åºç”šè‡³ä¸ç”ŸæˆèŠ‚ç‚¹åç§°ã€‚
This section has taken these complicated cases into account, and provide the corresponding solution, so that users can easily prepare the input data.
æœ¬èŠ‚è€ƒè™‘äº†è¿™äº›å¤æ‚çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œå¹¶æä¾›äº†ç›¸åº”çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿ç”¨æˆ·å¯ä»¥è½»æ¾å‡†å¤‡è¾“å…¥æ•°æ®ã€‚

This basic grammar for range id is written as: branch_A|branch_B.
èŒƒå›´ id çš„åŸºæœ¬è¯­æ³•å†™ä¸ºï¼šbranch_A|branch_Bã€‚
This section provides an example of how to collapse branches using dataset 1 (refer to the Dataset for detail information) document for detailed information). Users can download the data locally from the provided link above. The files are read using a relative path in this document, so please adjust the path based on actual situation.
æœ¬èŠ‚æä¾›äº†å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨æ•°æ®é›† 1 æŠ˜å åˆ†æ”¯çš„ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼ˆè¯¦ç»†ä¿¡æ¯è¯·å‚é˜…æ•°æ®é›†æ–‡æ¡£ï¼‰ã€‚ç”¨æˆ·å¯ä»¥ä»ä¸Šé¢æä¾›çš„é“¾æ¥æœ¬åœ°ä¸‹è½½æ•°æ®ã€‚æœ¬æ–‡æ¡£é‡‡ç”¨ç›¸å¯¹è·¯å¾„è¯»å–æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œè¯·æ ¹æ®å®é™…æƒ…å†µè°ƒæ•´è·¯å¾„ã€‚
The first step is to load the newick format tree file tree_of_itol_templates.tree and its corresponding metadata template_groups.
ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥æ˜¯åŠ è½½newickæ ¼å¼æ ‘æ–‡ä»¶tree_of_itol_templates.treeåŠå…¶å¯¹åº”çš„å…ƒæ•°æ®template_groupsã€‚
library(itol.toolkit) tree <- system.file("extdata", "tree_of_itol_templates.tree", package = "itol.toolkit") data("template_groups") å¤åˆ¶
Suppose that the user wants to collapse DATASET_SIMPLEBAR and DATASET_MULTIBAR into one branch; DATASET_TEXT and LABELS into another branch;DATASET_ALIGNMENT, DATASET_CONNECTIONS, DATASET_IMAGE and POPUP_INFO which belong to advanced visualization into one branch:
å‡è®¾ç”¨æˆ·æƒ³è¦å°† DATASET_SIMPLEBAR å’Œ DATASET_MULTIBAR æŠ˜å æˆä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ï¼› DATASET_TEXT å’Œ LABELS æ”¾åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ï¼›DATASET_ALIGNMENTã€DATASET_CONNECTIONSã€DATASET_IMAGE å’Œ POPUP_INFO å±äºé«˜çº§å¯è§†åŒ–åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ï¼š
range_ids <- c("DATASET_SIMPLEBAR|DATASET_MULTIBAR", "DATASET_TEXT|LABELS", "DATASET_CONNECTIONS|POPUP_INFO") unit_1 <- create_unit(data = range_ids, key = "E001_collapse_1", type = "COLLAPSE", tree = tree) write_unit(unit_1, paste0(getwd(),"/E001_collapse_1.txt")) å¤åˆ¶

While the first two sets of folded branches are relatively simple to define because no other branches exist between them, the third set of folded branches is slightly complex, requiring the user to select the two branches with the longest spacing among the four to accurately describe the extent to be folded. Writing the code as DATASET_ALIGNMENT | POPUP_INFO may result in the omission of the DATASET_CONNECTIONS branch, because the branch does not belong to MCRA of DATASET_ALIGNMENT and POPUP_INFO.
è™½ç„¶å‰ä¸¤ç»„æŠ˜å åˆ†æ”¯å®šä¹‰ç›¸å¯¹ç®€å•ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬ä¹‹é—´ä¸å­˜åœ¨å…¶ä»–åˆ†æ”¯ï¼Œä½†ç¬¬ä¸‰ç»„æŠ˜å åˆ†æ”¯ç¨å¾®å¤æ‚ï¼Œéœ€è¦ç”¨æˆ·é€‰æ‹©å››ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ä¸­é—´è·æœ€é•¿çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯æ¥å‡†ç¡®æè¿°æŠ˜å çš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚å°†ä»£ç ç¼–å†™ä¸º DATASET_ALIGNMENT | POPUP_INFO å¯èƒ½ä¼šå¯¼è‡´çœç•¥ DATASET_CONNECTIONS åˆ†æ”¯ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¯¥åˆ†æ”¯ä¸å±äº DATASET_ALIGNMENT å’Œ POPUP_INFO çš„ MCRAã€‚
Because the process of defining branches is very cumbersome and requires manual judgment, this function is not used frequently in the 23 templates in iTOL v6.
ç”±äºå®šä¹‰åˆ†æ”¯çš„è¿‡ç¨‹éå¸¸ç¹çï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”éœ€è¦æ‰‹åŠ¨åˆ¤æ–­ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¯¥åŠŸèƒ½åœ¨iTOL v6çš„23ä¸ªæ¨¡æ¿ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨é¢‘ç‡å¹¶ä¸é«˜ã€‚

Although we used a tip label in the above example, using node names directly is more convenient if it is available. Thus, the itol.toolkit also enable you to define the collapsed branch using the node name directly .
å°½ç®¡æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ä¸Šé¢çš„ç¤ºä¾‹ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨äº†æç¤ºæ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œä½†å¦‚æœå¯ä»¥çš„è¯ï¼Œç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨èŠ‚ç‚¹åç§°ä¼šæ›´æ–¹ä¾¿ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œitol.toolkit è¿˜å…è®¸æ‚¨ç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨èŠ‚ç‚¹åç§°å®šä¹‰æŠ˜å åˆ†æ”¯ã€‚
The tree provided by itol.toolkit dataset 1 including the node labels:
itol.toolkit æ•°æ®é›† 1 æä¾›çš„æ ‘åŒ…æ‹¬èŠ‚ç‚¹æ ‡ç­¾ï¼š
ape::read.tree(tree) # Phylogenetic tree with 23 tips and 22 internal nodes. # # Tip labels: # SPACING, COLLAPSE, PRUNE, TREE_COLORS, DATASET_STYLE, DATASET_CONNECTIONS, ... # Node labels: # I1, I2, tree_sturcture, I4, theme_style, I6, ... # # Rooted; includes branch lengths. å¤åˆ¶
Therefore, you could specify the group you want to merge directly.
å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ‚¨å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥æŒ‡å®šè¦åˆå¹¶çš„ç»„ã€‚
group_names <- unique(c("tree_sturcture", "theme_style", "text", "basic_plot")) unit_2 <- create_unit(data = group_names, key = "E002_collapse_2", type = "COLLAPSE", tree = tree) write_unit(unit_2, paste0(getwd(),"/E002_collapse_2.txt")) å¤åˆ¶

If you have questions about how to upload results files from iTOL toolkit for interactive visualization on iTOL, please refer to the Operation document for step-by-step guidance.
å¦‚æœæ‚¨å¯¹å¦‚ä½•ä» iTOL å·¥å…·åŒ…ä¸Šä¼ ç»“æœæ–‡ä»¶ä»¥åœ¨ iTOL ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œäº¤äº’å¼å¯è§†åŒ–æœ‰ç–‘é—®ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜…æ“ä½œæ–‡æ¡£ä»¥è·å–åˆ†æ­¥æŒ‡å¯¼ã€‚

item.title: ç›¸å…³æ€§çƒ­å›¾
item.description:
åŸæ–‡é“¾æ¥
ç›¸å…³æ€§æ˜¯æŒ‡ä¸¤ä¸ªæˆ–å¤šä¸ªå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„å…³ç³»ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚åœ¨ç»Ÿè®¡å­¦ä¸­ï¼Œå¸¸ç”¨ç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°æ¥è¡¡é‡å˜é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸å…³æ€§ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æœ€å¸¸è§çš„æ˜¯çš®å°”é€Šç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°ã€‚ç›¸å…³æ€§ç³»æ•°çš„å–å€¼èŒƒå›´åœ¨-1åˆ°1ä¹‹é—´ï¼Œ-1è¡¨ç¤ºå®Œå…¨çš„è´Ÿç›¸å…³ï¼Œ1è¡¨ç¤ºå®Œå…¨çš„æ­£ç›¸å…³ï¼Œ0è¡¨ç¤ºæ²¡æœ‰çº¿æ€§ç›¸å…³æ€§ã€‚
ç›¸å…³æ€§å›¾æ˜¯ä¸€ç§å¯è§†åŒ–æ‰‹æ®µï¼Œç”¨äºå±•ç¤ºå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸å…³å…³ç³»ã€‚è¿™ç§å›¾å½¢é€šå¸¸ä»¥çŸ©é˜µçš„å½¢å¼å‘ˆç°ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æ¯ä¸ªå•å…ƒæ ¼è¡¨ç¤ºä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°ã€‚å›¾å½¢çš„é¢œè‰²å’Œå½¢çŠ¶å¯ä»¥è¡¨ç¤ºç›¸å…³æ€§çš„å¼ºå¼±ï¼Œä»è€Œç›´è§‚åœ°å¸®åŠ©æˆ‘ä»¬ç†è§£æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„å…³è”æ¨¡å¼ã€‚
ç›¸å…³æ€§è¯¦è§ï¼šé“¾æ¥ã€‚

R åŒ… corrplot æä¾›äº†å¾ˆå¥½çš„ç›¸å…³çŸ©é˜µçš„å¯è§†åŒ–æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä¸ä»…åœ¨å›¾å½¢å¸ƒå±€ã€é¢œè‰²ã€å›¾ä¾‹ã€æ–‡æœ¬æ ‡ç­¾ç­‰æ–¹é¢æä¾›äº†ä¸°å¯Œçš„ç»˜å›¾é€‰é¡¹,è¿˜æä¾› p å€¼å’Œç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´æ¥ç¡®å®šç›¸å…³æ€§çš„ç»Ÿè®¡æ˜¾ç€æ€§ã€‚corrplotæ–¹æ³•æœ‰å¤§çº¦ 50 ä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼Œæœ€å¸¸ç”¨çš„å‚æ•°æœ‰methodã€typeã€orderã€diagç­‰ã€‚
# å®‰è£…RåŒ… å¤åˆ¶
ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå¸¦çš„mtcarsæ•°æ®é›†
# ?mtcars # A data frame with 32 observations on 11 (numeric) variables. # > mtcars # mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb # Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4 # Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 4 4 # Datsun 710 22.8 4 108.0 93 3.85 2.320 18.61 1 1 4 1 # Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258.0 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 3 1 å¤åˆ¶
è®¡ç®—ç›¸å…³æ€§çŸ©é˜µ
cordata = cor(mtcars) å¤åˆ¶
ä½¿ç”¨é»˜è®¤å‚æ•°ç»˜å›¾
corrplot(cordata, ) # method = 'circle' å¤åˆ¶

ä½¿ç”¨methodã€orderã€typeã€diag å‚æ•°è°ƒæ•´å›¾å½¢ï¼
# ä»å·¦åˆ°å³ ç¬¬ä¸€æ’ color->shade->square corrplot(cordata, method = 'color', order = 'alphabet') corrplot(cordata, method = 'shade', order = 'AOE', diag = FALSE) corrplot(cordata, method = 'square', order = 'FPC', type = 'lower', diag = FALSE) # ä»å·¦åˆ°å³ ç¬¬äºŒæ’ corrplot(cordata, method = 'ellipse', order = 'AOE', type = 'upper') corrplot.mixed(cordata, order = 'AOE') corrplot.mixed(cordata, lower = 'shade', upper = 'pie', order = 'hclust') å¤åˆ¶

# å®‰è£… if(!require(devtools)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("kassambara/ggcorrplot") library(ggcorrplot) p1 <- ggcorrplot(cordata, method = "circle") p2 <- ggcorrplot(cordata, hc.order = TRUE, outline.col = "white") p3 <- ggcorrplot(cordata, hc.order = TRUE, type = "upper", outline.col = "white") p4 <- ggcorrplot(cordata, hc.order = TRUE, type = "lower", lab = TRUE) å¤åˆ¶

# install remotes package if necessary install.packages("remotes") # install corrmorant from the github repository remotes::install_github("r-link/corrmorant") # correlation plot of the drosera data using style = 'light' corrmorant(drosera, style = "light") # the "dark" style has a dark background in the diagonal facets corrmorant(drosera, style = "dark") # in the "blue_red" style, colors and correlation labels are colored by the strength of # correlation corrmorant(drosera, style = "blue_red") å¤åˆ¶
library(tidyverse) select(mtcars, mpg, disp:qsec) %>% ggcorrm(rescale = "by_sd") + utri_heatmap(alpha = 0.5) + lotri_heatcircle(alpha = 0.5, col = 1) + utri_corrtext() + dia_names(y_pos = 0.15, size = 3) + dia_density(lower = 0.3, fill = "lightgrey", color = 1) + scale_fill_corr() å¤åˆ¶

install.packages('pheatmap') # æ¨¡æ‹Ÿæ•°æ® library(pheatmap) # Data set.seed(8) m <- matrix(rnorm(200), 10, 10) colnames(m) <- paste("Col", 1:10) rownames(m) <- paste("Row", 1:10) # ç»˜åˆ¶ Heat mapï¼Œ å¹¶æŒ‰ç…§åˆ—å½’ä¸€åŒ– pheatmap(m, scale = "column") # å‚æ•°è°ƒæ•´ # display_numbers pheatmap(m, display_numbers = TRUE, number_color = "black", fontsize_number = 8) # kmeansèšç±» pheatmap(m, kmeans_k = 3, cellheight = 50) # border_color pheatmap(m, border_color = "black") # Color palette pheatmap(m, color = hcl.colors(50, "BluYl")) å¤åˆ¶

install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("hannet91/ggcor") library(ggplot2) library(ggcor) library(vegan) library(dplyr) data("varechem") data("varespec") fortify_mantel(varespec, varechem, spec.select = list(1:10, 5:14, 7:22, 9:32)) %>% mutate(r = cut(r, breaks = c(-Inf, 0.25, 0.5, Inf), labels = c("<0.25", "0.25-0.5", ">=0.5"), right = FALSE), p.value = cut(p.value, breaks = c(-Inf, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, Inf), labels = c("<0.001", "0.001-0.01", "0.01-0.05", ">=0.05"), right = FALSE)) quickcor(varechem, type = "upper") + geom_square() + add_link(mantel02, mapping = aes(colour = p.value, size = r), diag.label = TRUE) + scale_size_manual(values = c(0.5, 1.5, 3)) + add_diag_label() + remove_axis("x") å¤åˆ¶


# å®‰è£…PerformanceAnalytics install.packages("PerformanceAnalytics") # ç»˜åˆ¶æ•£ç‚¹çŸ©é˜µ chart.Correlation(mtcars[,1:8], histogram=TRUE) å¤åˆ¶

# å®‰è£… install.packages('GGally') library(GGally) library(ggplot2) # è‡ªå¸¦çš„irisæ•°æ®é›† ggpairs(iris, columns=1:5, aes(color=Species)) + ggtitle("Iris (GGally_ggpairs) ")+ theme_bw() å¤åˆ¶

panel.hist <- function(x, ...) { usr <- par("usr"); on.exit(par(usr)) par(usr = c(usr[1:2], 0, 1.5) ) h <- hist(x, plot = FALSE) breaks <- h$breaks; nB <- length(breaks) y <- h$counts; y <- y/max(y) rect(breaks[-nB], 0, breaks[-1], y, col = "cyan", ...)} pairs(iris[1:5], main = "Iris(pairs)", pch = 21, panel = panel.smooth, diag.panel = panel.hist, bg = c("#1b9e77", "#d95f02", "#7570b3")[unclass(iris$Species)] å¤åˆ¶

# å®‰è£… install.packages("psych") library(psych) # ç»˜å›¾ pairs.panels(iris, smooth = TRUE, # If TRUE, draws loess smooths scale = FALSE, # If TRUE, scales the correlation text font density = TRUE, # If TRUE, adds density plots and histograms ellipses = TRUE, # If TRUE, draws ellipses method = "pearson", # Correlation method (also "spearman" or "kendall") pch = 21, # pch symbol lm = FALSE, # If TRUE, plots linear fit rather than the LOESS (smoothed) fit cor = TRUE, # If TRUE, reports correlations jiggle = FALSE, # If TRUE, data points are jittered factor = 2, # Jittering factor hist.col = 4, # Histograms color stars = TRUE, # If TRUE, adds significance level with stars ci = TRUE) # If TRUE, adds confidence intervals å¤åˆ¶

æ•£ç‚¹å›¾æ˜¯æœ€å¸¸ç”¨çš„å›¾å½¢ã€‚æ¯å½“ä½ æƒ³äº†è§£ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´å…³ç³»çš„æœ¬è´¨æ—¶ï¼Œé¦–é€‰æ€»æ˜¯æ•£ç‚¹å›¾ã€‚åœ¨ggplot2ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ geom_point() å¯ä»¥ç»˜åˆ¶æ•£ç‚¹å›¾ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œgeom_smooth é»˜è®¤ç»˜åˆ¶å¹³æ»‘çº¿ï¼ˆåŸºäº loessï¼‰ï¼Œå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è®¾ç½® method='lm' è°ƒæ•´ä¸ºç»˜åˆ¶æœ€ä½³æ‹Ÿåˆçº¿ã€‚
library('tidyverse') pal = c('#025259', '#007172', '#f4e2de', '#f29325', '#d94f04') ggplot(data = midwest %>% filter(poptotal<=200000), aes(x=area, y=poptotal)) + geom_point(aes(fill=state), shape=21, color="black") + geom_smooth(se=FALSE, color=pal[1]) + scale_fill_manual(values = pal) + scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(50000, 200000, 50000)) + labs(title = 'ScatterPlot', subtitle = 'Area vs Poptotal', caption = 'source: midwest') + theme_minimal() + theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 20, face = 'bold', hjust = 0), plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 14, hjust = 0), plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12, face = 'italic', hjust = 1), plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'white', color='white'), axis.text = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12), axis.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 16, face = 'bold')) å¤åˆ¶


æ•£ç‚¹å›¾å¯ä»¥è®©æ‚¨æ¯”è¾ƒä¸¤ä¸ªè¿ç»­å˜é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„å…³ç³»ï¼Œè€Œæ°”æ³¡å›¾åˆ™å¯ä»¥å¾ˆå¥½åœ°å¸®åŠ©æ‚¨äº†è§£åŸºæœ¬ç»„å†…çš„å…³ç³»ï¼šä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†ç±»å˜é‡ï¼ˆé€šè¿‡æ”¹å˜é¢œè‰²ï¼‰å’Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªè¿ç»­å˜é‡ï¼ˆé€šè¿‡æ”¹å˜ç‚¹çš„å¤§å°ï¼‰ã€‚å¦‚æœæ‚¨æœ‰å››ç»´æ•°æ®ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ä¸¤ä¸ªæ˜¯æ•°å€¼å˜é‡ï¼ˆX å’Œ Yï¼‰ï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯åˆ†ç±»å˜é‡ï¼ˆé¢œè‰²ï¼‰å’Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å€¼å˜é‡ï¼ˆå¤§å°ï¼‰ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆæ°”æ³¡å›¾å°±æ¯”è¾ƒé€‚åˆã€‚
æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ä¹‹å‰çš„æ•£ç‚¹å›¾ä¸­å±•ç°äº†ç¾å›½ä¸åŒå¿çš„é¢ç§¯ï¼ˆXè½´ï¼‰ä¸æ€»äººå£ï¼ˆYè½´ï¼‰ä¹‹é—´çš„å…³ç³»ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”ç”¨å¿æ‰€å±çš„å·æ¥æ˜ å°„é¢œè‰²ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨æ­¤åŸºç¡€ä¹‹ä¸Šï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å„ä¸ªå¿ä¸­äºšæ´²äººçš„æ•°é‡æ¥æ˜ å°„ç‚¹çš„å¤§å°ï¼Œå°±å¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°æ°”æ³¡å›¾äº†ã€‚
library('tidyverse') pal = c('#025259', '#007172', '#f4e2de', '#f29325', '#d94f04') ggplot(data = midwest %>% filter(poptotal<=200000), aes(x=area, y=poptotal)) + geom_point(aes(fill=state, size=popasian), shape=21, alpha=0.85) + scale_fill_manual(values = pal) + scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(50000, 200000, 50000), expand = c(0, 0), limits = c(0, 210000)) + scale_size(range = c(1, 12)) + labs(title = 'Bubble Plot', subtitle = 'Area vs Poptotal', caption = 'source: midwest') + theme_minimal() + theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 20, face = 'bold', hjust = 0), plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 14, hjust = 0), plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12, face = 'italic', hjust = 1), plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'white', color='white'), axis.text = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12), axis.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 16, face = 'bold')) å¤åˆ¶


ggplot(data=midwest %>% filter(poptotal<=200000), aes(x=area, y=poptotal)) + geom_point(aes(fill=state, size=popasian), alpha=0.8, shape=21, color="black") + geom_polygon(data=midwest %>% filter(poptotal<=200000 & state=="OH") %>% slice(chull(.$area, .$poptotal)), color="grey30", fill="gold", alpha=0.1) + scale_size(range = c(1, 12)) + scale_fill_manual(values = pal) + labs(subtitle="Area Vs Population", y="Population", x="Area", title="Scatterplot + Encircle", caption="Source: midwest") + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) + theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 20, face = 'bold', hjust = 0), plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 14, hjust = 0), plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12, face = 'italic', hjust = 1), plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'white', color='white'), axis.text = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12), axis.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 16, face = 'bold')) å¤åˆ¶


mpg %>% filter(cyl %in% c(4, 8)) %>% mutate(cyl = as.factor(cyl)) %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x=displ, y=hwy, fill=cyl, color=cyl)) + geom_point(color='black', shape=21, size=3) + geom_smooth(method = 'lm', fullrange=TRUE, alpha=0.3) + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0.5, 7.5), expand = c(0, 0)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = c(0, 0)) + scale_fill_manual(values = c('#025259', '#f29325'), guide = guide_legend(ncol=1))+ scale_color_manual(values = c('#025259', '#f29325')) + labs(subtitle="Cyl Vs Displ", y="Cyl", x="Displ", title="Scatterplot with Fitted Lines", caption="Source: mpg") + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) + theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 20, face = 'bold', hjust = 0), plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 14, hjust = 0), plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12, face = 'italic', hjust = 1), plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'white', color='white'), axis.text = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12), axis.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 16, face = 'bold')) å¤åˆ¶


mpg %>% ggplot(aes(x=cyl, y=hwy, fill=as.factor(cyl))) + geom_point(shape=21, size=3.5, color='black') + scale_fill_manual(name ='CYL', values = pal) + labs(title = 'Scatterplot with overlapping points', subtitle = 'mpg: cyl vs highway mileage', caption = 'source:mpg', x= 'Cyl', y= 'Hwy') + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) + theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 20, face = 'bold', hjust = 0), plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 14, hjust = 0), plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12, face = 'italic', hjust = 1), plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'white', color='white'), axis.text = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12), axis.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 16, face = 'bold')) å¤åˆ¶

å€¼å¾—æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæ•°æ®å­˜åœ¨é‡å çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œ å¾ˆå¤šæ•£ç‚¹è¢«éšè—äº†ã€‚ç”±äºctyå’Œhvyä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡éƒ½æ˜¯æ•´æ•°ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ•°æ®é‡å çš„ç°è±¡æ›´åŠ ä¸¥é‡ã€‚å¯¹äºè¿™ç±»æ•°æ®é›†çš„æ•£ç‚¹å›¾ï¼Œå±•ç¤ºè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­åº”è¯¥æ ¼å¤–å°å¿ƒã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆåº”è¯¥å¦‚ä½•è§£å†³ä¸€ä¸ªé—®é¢˜å‘¢ï¼Ÿæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨jitter_geom()å¯¹æ•°æ®å¢åŠ æŠ–åŠ¨ï¼Œé€šè¿‡è®¾ç½®wigthï¼Œä½¿å¾—é‡å çš„ç‚¹åœ¨åŸå§‹ä½ç½®éšæœºæŠ–åŠ¨ã€‚
mpg %>% ggplot(aes(x=cyl, y=hwy)) + geom_jitter(aes(fill=as.factor(cyl)), shape=21, color='black', width = 0.35, size=3.5) + scale_fill_manual(name='CYL', values = pal) + labs(title = 'Jittered Plot Points', subtitle = 'map: city vs highway mileage', caption = 'source:mpg', x= 'City', y= 'Highway') + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) + theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 20, face = 'bold', hjust = 0), plot.subtitle = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 14, hjust = 0), plot.caption = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12, face = 'italic', hjust = 1), plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'white', color='white'), axis.text = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 12), axis.title = element_text(color = "grey20", size = 16, face = 'bold')) å¤åˆ¶

ç«¯ç‚¹ï¼šå°æç´çš„ç«¯ç‚¹è¡¨ç¤ºæ•°æ®çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼å’Œæœ€å°å€¼ã€‚


ä¸ç®±çº¿å›¾çš„æ¯”è¾ƒï¼šå°æç´å›¾èƒ½å¤ŸåŒæ—¶æ˜¾ç¤ºæ•°æ®çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå½¢çŠ¶å’Œå¯†åº¦ï¼Œè€Œç®±çº¿å›¾åªèƒ½æä¾›åˆ†ä½æ•°ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚å°æç´å›¾å¯ä»¥å‘ç°æ•°æ®çš„åŒå³°åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œè€Œç®±çº¿å›¾æ— æ³•æ•æ‰è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µã€‚
ä¸ç›´æ–¹å›¾çš„æ¯”è¾ƒï¼šå°æç´å›¾åœ¨å¯è§†åŒ–æ•°æ®åˆ†å¸ƒçš„åŒæ—¶ï¼Œé¿å…äº†ç›´æ–¹å›¾çš„åˆ†ç®±è¯¯å·®ã€‚å°æç´å›¾å¯ä»¥æ¸…æ™°åœ°å±•ç¤ºæ•°æ®çš„å³°å€¼å’Œå½¢çŠ¶ï¼Œè€Œç›´æ–¹å›¾å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ¨¡ç³Šè¿™äº›ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚
ä¸æ•£ç‚¹å›¾çš„æ¯”è¾ƒï¼šå°æç´å›¾é€‚ç”¨äºå¤§é‡æ•°æ®ï¼Œå¯ä»¥æ›´å¥½åœ°å±•ç¤ºå¯†åº¦åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œè€Œæ•£ç‚¹å›¾å¯èƒ½ä¼šå› ä¸ºæ•°æ®ç‚¹çš„é‡å è€Œå¤±å»ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚æ•£ç‚¹å›¾é€šå¸¸ç”¨äºæ˜¾ç¤ºä¸ªä½“æ•°æ®ç‚¹çš„åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œè€Œå°æç´å›¾æ›´é€‚åˆäºæ€»ä½“åˆ†å¸ƒçš„æè¿°ã€‚
ä¸å¯†åº¦å›¾çš„æ¯”è¾ƒï¼šå°æç´å›¾å¯ä»¥åŒæ—¶æ˜¾ç¤ºå¤šä¸ªåˆ†ç»„çš„åˆ†å¸ƒæƒ…å†µï¼Œè€Œå¯†åº¦å›¾é€šå¸¸é€‚ç”¨äºå•ä¸€åˆ†å¸ƒçš„æƒ…å†µã€‚
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(warpbreaks, aes(x = tension, y = breaks)) +
geom_violin()

ggplot(warpbreaks, aes(x = tension, y = breaks)) +
geom_violin(trim = FALSE)

ggplot(warpbreaks, aes(x = tension, y = breaks)) +
geom_violin(trim = FALSE)+
geom_boxplot(width = 0.07)

geom_violin(trim = FALSE,bw = 5) +

geom_violin(trim = FALSE) +

library(ggpubr)
ggplot(warpbreaks, aes(x = tension, y = breaks, fill = wool)) +

stat_compare_means(aes(label = ..p.signif..),method = "wilcox.test",hide.ns = F)

geom_violin(trim = FALSE,bw = 5) +

guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Title"))+

item.title: å¤§è§„æ¨¡å¹¶è¡Œæµ‹åºçš„çº¿ç²’ä½“åŸºå› ç»„è§£é‡Šäº†å£®ä¾—è¯­çš„æµ·å—é»æ—æ¯ç³»å¤šæ ·å’Œé—ä¼ ç»“æ„
item.description: As a single maternally inherited locus, human mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is geographically arranged and plays a key role in forensic applications. Hlai population has been evidenced as the most typical and unmixed representative of the Tai-Kadai-speaking populations via genome-wide analyses. However, forensic features and maternal diversity of the complete mitogenomes in this Tai-Kadai ancestrally related population are scarce. Thus, we sequenced the complete mitogenomes in 127 Hainan Hlais and found 109 distinct haplotypes belonging to 43 terminal haplogroups resulting in the haplotype diversity of 0.9970. Our results of comprehensive population comparisons showed that Hlai islanders had a close genetic affinity with Tai-Kadai-speaking populations from Southeast Asia, which is consistent with the back-migration of Chinese Neolithic farmers into this region via the inland route. Besides, maternally genetic evidence further revealed a close genetic relationship between Tai-Kadai-speaking and Austronesian-speaking populations when only East Asian dataset was considered, which is consistent with the common origin from Yangtze rice farmers ç¨»ï¼ˆOryza sativa L.ï¼‰å†œä¸šand then spread southward along the inlandå†…é™† and coastalæ²¿æµ· routes, respectively. In the reconstructed phylogenetic tree and median-joining networks, the vast majority of Hlais were clustered in exclusive clades, which demonstrated that Hlai people probably had undergone founder effect or genetic bottleneck ç“¶é¢ˆæ•ˆåº”ï¼ˆbottleneckï¼‰in their history, and remained genetically isolated for a long time. Collectively, Hainan Hlai did not exhibit detectable maternal gene flow from surrounding or incoming populations. Mitogenome information generated in this study is a contribution in mitigating the underrepresentation of Chinese data in forensic mitogenetics and will assist geography-, metapopulation-, as well as phylogeny-based queries.

item.description:
A call for mtDNA data quality control in forensic science

â€œUnfortunately, many published mtDNA data are not sufficiently reliable [13], thus strongly limiting their forensic use.â€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 1) ä¸å¹¸çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè®¸å¤šå·²å‘è¡¨çš„çº¿ç²’ä½“DNAæ•°æ®ä¸å¤Ÿå¯é [13]ï¼Œå› æ­¤æå¤§åœ°é™åˆ¶äº†å®ƒä»¬çš„æ³•åŒ»ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚
â€œbase shifts, reference bias, phantom mutations, base misscoring, and artificial recombinationâ€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 1) 5ç§é”™è¯¯ï¼š

ç¢±åŸºç§»ä½
å‚è€ƒåå·®
å¹»å½±çªå˜
ç¢±åŸºé”™è¯¯è¯„åˆ†
äººå·¥é‡ç»„
â€œIf, in a sequence composed of several independently generated mtDNA fragments, chunks of mutations from one segment signifying one haplogroup co-occur with chunks of mutations from another segment that define another haplogroup, then one would see clear evidence for artificial recombination between two generated mtDNA lineages.â€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 2) å¦‚æœåœ¨ç”±å‡ ä¸ªç‹¬ç«‹ç”Ÿæˆçš„ mtDNA ç‰‡æ®µç»„æˆçš„åºåˆ—ä¸­ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºä¸€ä¸ªå•å€ç¾¤çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç‰‡æ®µçš„çªå˜å—ä¸å®šä¹‰å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå•å€ç¾¤çš„å¦ä¸€ä¸ªç‰‡æ®µçš„çªå˜å—åŒæ—¶å‡ºç°ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆäººä»¬å°±ä¼šçœ‹åˆ°ä¸¤ä¸ªç”Ÿæˆçš„ mtDNA ä¹‹é—´äººå·¥é‡ç»„çš„æ˜ç¡®è¯æ®è¡€ç»Ÿã€‚
â€œRather than distinguishing between fast- and slowmutating sites, we discriminate between fast transitions and slower mutations.â€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 2) æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸æ˜¯åŒºåˆ†å¿«çªå˜ä½ç‚¹å’Œæ…¢çªå˜ä½ç‚¹ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯åŒºåˆ†å¿«çªå˜å’Œæ…¢çªå˜ã€‚åè€…åŒ…å«å‰©ä½™çš„è½¬æ¢ä»¥åŠæ‰€æœ‰é¢ æ¢ã€ç¼ºå¤±å’Œæ’å…¥ï¼Œä½† C å»¶ä¼¸å’Œä¾§ç¿¼çŸ­ A å»¶ä¼¸çš„é•¿åº¦å¤šæ€æ€§é™¤å¤–ï¼Œç³»ç»Ÿå‘è‚²åˆ†æé€šå¸¸å¿½ç•¥å®ƒä»¬ã€‚

â€œSome authors, enforced by a requirement of Lincoln and Carracedo [41], claimed that â€˜â€˜the sequence data are available from the authors on requestâ€™â€™, but actually they do not always reply to the request for the data.â€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 4) ä¸€äº›ä½œè€…æ ¹æ® Lincoln å’Œ Carracedo çš„è¦æ±‚ï¼Œå£°ç§°â€œåºåˆ—æ•°æ®å¯æ ¹æ®ä½œè€…çš„è¦æ±‚æä¾›â€ï¼Œä½†å®é™…ä¸Šä»–ä»¬å¹¶ä¸æ€»æ˜¯å›å¤å¯¹æ•°æ®çš„è¯·æ±‚ã€‚
â€œThe â€˜â€˜D-Loop-BASEâ€™â€™ project initiated by Wittig et al. [42] is problematic in this respect, as â€˜â€˜individual sequences will not be publishedâ€™â€™ [43].â€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 4) Wittig ç­‰äººå‘èµ·çš„â€œD-Loop-BASEâ€é¡¹ç›®ã€‚ [42]åœ¨è¿™æ–¹é¢æ˜¯æœ‰é—®é¢˜çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºâ€œå•ä¸ªåºåˆ—ä¸ä¼šè¢«å‘å¸ƒâ€[43]ã€‚
â€œIn summary, we still have every reason to question the quality of the mtDNA data published in forensic science. It does not seem that the alarming news of 2001 have led to a noticeable improvement of data quality so far. For instance, we expect that more than 20% of the 105 mtDNA sequences published by Rao et al. [8] harbor obvious errors, such as trivial editing errors (resulting in base shifts) and artificial recombination (crossover between different lineages). It is axiomatic that such data are rather useless for forensic purposes. Therefore, researchers who provide data, peer reviewers, and journal editors are urged to take the possibility of serious errors into consideration and to subject the data a thorough a posteriori analysis.â€ (Yao ç­‰, 2004, p. 4) ç»¼ä¸Šæ‰€è¿°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç„¶æœ‰å……åˆ†çš„ç†ç”±è´¨ç–‘æ³•åŒ»å­¦å‘è¡¨çš„çº¿ç²’ä½“DNAæ•°æ®çš„è´¨é‡ã€‚è¿„ä»Šä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œ2001 å¹´çš„ä»¤äººéœ‡æƒŠçš„æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼¼ä¹å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰å¯¼è‡´æ•°æ®è´¨é‡çš„æ˜¾ç€æ”¹å–„ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é¢„è®¡ Rao ç­‰äººå‘è¡¨çš„ 105 ä¸ª mtDNA åºåˆ—ä¸­è¶…è¿‡ 20% [8]å­˜åœ¨æ˜æ˜¾çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å¾®ä¸è¶³é“çš„ç¼–è¾‘é”™è¯¯ï¼ˆå¯¼è‡´ç¢±åŸºç§»ä½ï¼‰å’Œäººå·¥é‡ç»„ï¼ˆä¸åŒè°±ç³»ä¹‹é—´çš„äº¤å‰ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸è¨€è€Œå–»çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ•°æ®å¯¹äºæ³•åŒ»ç›®çš„æ¯«æ— ç”¨å¤„ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ•¦ä¿ƒæä¾›æ•°æ®çš„ç ”ç©¶äººå‘˜ã€åŒè¡Œè¯„å®¡å‘˜å’ŒæœŸåˆŠç¼–è¾‘è€ƒè™‘å‡ºç°ä¸¥é‡é”™è¯¯çš„å¯èƒ½æ€§ï¼Œå¹¶å¯¹æ•°æ®è¿›è¡Œå½»åº•çš„äº‹ååˆ†æã€‚

item.title: Introduction
item.description:
Modern humans have experiencedexplosive population growth in the past thousand years. We hypothesized that recent human population have been accompanied by environments with relaxation of selective constraints, possibly due to the more abundant food supply after the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). The ratio of nonsynonymous to synonymous mutations (N/S ratio) is a useful and common statistic for measuring selective constraints. A higher N/S rati o may indicate weaker purifying selection.

We reconstructed a high-resolution phylogeny with a total of 26,419 East Eurasian _ mtDNA genomes and estimated coalescence time of each lineage. We identified the lineages existed at 25 kya as the founder lineages. We calculated the number of nonsynonymous and synonymous mutations, and N/S ratio accumulated for mtDNA sequences compared to their founder haplotypes (Figure 1).


An individual was classified into the expansion or non-expansion groups whether the frequency of its founder haplogroup was above 1%.
20,612 individuals in the expansion group and 5,807 individuals in the non-expansion group

The average number of derivednonsynonymous mutations in the expansion group was significantly higher (Figure 2a).
HC The average number of derived synonymous mutations in the expansion group (3.92 Â±1.83 ) was a little (approximately 8%) but still significantly higher than that in the non-expansion group (3.61 Â± 1.83) (Figure 2b), indicating that the expanded founder lineages might arise earlier than the non-expanded ones.
The N/S ratio in the expansion group (0.525 åœŸ0.003) was significantly higher than that in the non-expansion group (0.429 Â± 0.006) (Figure 2c), indicating relaxed purifying selection or positive selection in the expansion group.

Since hundreds of expansionlineages were involved in the major expansion process of East Eurasians after the LGM, we preferred to interpret that the expansions of numerous founder lineages were due to relaxation of purifying selection. Considering that the larger effective population size and the relatively longer coalescence time in the expansion group may have stronger effect of purifying selection, the remaining possibility for observing a higher N/S ratio in the expansion group was that the expanded populations were accompanied by relaxed selective constraints.

We further conduct forward simulations with same selective constraints.
The number of derivednonsynonymous and synonymous mutations in the expansion group were significantly higher, showing the same trend to our observations in East Eurasians (Figure 2d and 2e).
However, we found that the N/Sratio accumulated in the non-expansion group were significantly higher than that in the expansion group in the simulated data when the selective constraints were the same (Figure 2f), which showed the opposite trend to our observation in East Eurasians and validated our hypothesis.

Thus, we argue that the expandedpopulations subjected to weaker selective constraints than the non-expanded populations did.

item.title: æ€§åˆ«åè§çš„é€‚åº”å¡‘é€ äº†è—äººçš„å•äº²åŸºå› åº“
item.description:
Sex-biased adaptation shapes uniparental gene pools in Tibetans
â€œmultiple dispersals into theTibetan Plateau, which canbe briefly assigned intotwoepisodes (â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) å¤šæ¬¡æ‰©æ•£åˆ°é’è—é«˜åŸï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç®€å•åœ°åˆ†ä¸ºä¸¤æ®µï¼š

â€œThe ancient dispersal occurring during theUpper Paleolithic, even before thelast glacial maximum (LGM, 25â€“19 thousand years ago, ka), was traced back totheearly Eurasian Homo sapiensâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) å¤ä»£çš„æ‰©æ•£å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨æ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ™šæœŸï¼Œç”šè‡³åœ¨æœ«æ¬¡ç››å†°æœŸï¼ˆLGMï¼‰ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è¿½æº¯åˆ°æ—©æœŸçš„æ¬§äºšæ™ºäººæ¥æ”¶æ¥è‡ªå¤è€ä¸¹å°¼ç´¢ç“¦äººçš„åŸºå› æµã€‚
â€œThe recent expansion within themidHolocene was ascribed totheNeolithic farmers andherders mainly derived from northern Chinaâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) å…¨æ–°ä¸–ä¸­æœŸæœ€è¿‘çš„æ‰©å¼ è¢«å½’å› äºä¸»è¦æ¥è‡ªä¸­å›½åŒ—æ–¹çš„æ–°çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£å†œç‰§æ°‘ã€‚
â€œThe dissection ofuniparental markers reveals distinct patterns ofYchromosome andmtDNA profiles inmodern Tibetans. Theextremely ancient Ychromosome lineage,haplogroup D-M174 with ageestimationbefore theLGM ((32.5Â±11.5) ka),was prevalent (54.3%) inTibetansâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) å¯¹å•äº²æ ‡è®°çš„å‰–ææ­ç¤ºäº†ç°ä»£è—äºº Y æŸ“è‰²ä½“å’Œ mtDNA è°±çš„ç‹¬ç‰¹æ¨¡å¼ã€‚æå…¶å¤è€çš„YæŸ“è‰²ä½“è°±ç³»ï¼Œå•å€ç¾¤D-M174ï¼Œå¹´é¾„ä¼°è®¡åœ¨æœ«æ¬¡ç››ä¸–ä¹‹å‰ï¼ˆ32.5Â±11.5 kaï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨è—æ—äººä¸­æ™®éå­˜åœ¨ï¼ˆ54.3ï¼…ï¼‰ã€‚
â€œIncontrast, themost ancient indigenous mtDNA lineage, haplogroup M62 ((27.7Â±10.2) ka),existed with alow frequency of~2% (Zhao etal.,2009; Qiet al.,2013).â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) ç›¸æ¯”ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼Œæœ€å¤è€çš„æœ¬åœŸçº¿ç²’ä½“DNAè°±ç³»ï¼Œå•å€ç¾¤M62ï¼ˆï¼ˆ27.7Â±10.2ï¼‰kaï¼‰ï¼Œä»¥çº¦2%çš„è¾ƒä½é¢‘ç‡å­˜åœ¨ã€‚
â€œThe maternal gene pool of modern Tibetans was substantially shaped bytheNeolithic expansion of millet farmers from thelow-latitude Yellow River basin ofnorthern China, as characterized bytheprevalence ofmtDNA haplogroups such asM9a1a1c1b1a (5.9â€“3.7 ka)and A11a1a (10.2â€“3.3 ka)â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) ç°ä»£è—äººçš„æ¯ç³»åŸºå› åº“åœ¨å¾ˆå¤§ç¨‹åº¦ä¸Šæ˜¯ç”±æ¥è‡ªä¸­å›½åŒ—æ–¹ä½çº¬åº¦é»„æ²³æµåŸŸçš„ç²Ÿå†œçš„æ–°çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ‰©å¼ æ‰€å¡‘é€ çš„ï¼Œå…¶ç‰¹å¾æ˜¯çº¿ç²’ä½“DNAå•å€ç¾¤çš„æ™®éå­˜åœ¨ï¼Œå¦‚M9a1a1c1b1aï¼ˆ5.9-3.7 kaï¼‰å’ŒA11a1aï¼ˆ10.2-3.3 kaï¼‰ã€‚
â€œmodern Tibetans ischaracterized bythe lineages from Upper Paleolithic male hunter-gatherers from thehighlands and Neolithic female farmers from thelowlandsâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) ç°ä»£è—äººçš„è¡€ç»Ÿæ˜¯æ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ™šæœŸæ¥è‡ªé«˜åœ°çš„ç”·æ€§ç‹©çŒé‡‡é›†è€…å’Œæ–°çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ¥è‡ªä½åœ°çš„å¥³æ€§å†œæ°‘çš„è¡€ç»Ÿã€‚
â€œThis sex-biased pattern has not been explained yet.â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) ä»¤äººè´¹è§£çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œç°ä»£è—äººæ‹¥æœ‰å¦‚æ­¤ä¹‹å¤šï¼ˆ>50%ï¼‰çš„æ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ™šæœŸçˆ¶ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯æ¥å—äº†æ–°çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£å†œä¸šå­¦å®¶çš„å¹¿æ³›é—ä¼ è´¡çŒ®ã€‚è¿™ç§æ€§åˆ«åè§æ¨¡å¼å°šæœªå¾—åˆ°è§£é‡Šã€‚
â€œhigh- and low-altitudes presented anatlas ofthe adaptive traits innative Tibetans, in which some showed sex-biased phenotypicdifferences (â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) é«˜æµ·æ‹”å’Œä½æµ·æ‹”åœ°åŒºå‘ˆç°å‡ºè—æ—æœ¬åœŸé€‚åº”æ€§ç‰¹å¾çš„å›¾è°±ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ä¸€äº›è¡¨ç°å‡ºæ€§åˆ«åå‘çš„è¡¨å‹å·®å¼‚ã€‚
â€œInthe Tibetan samples, themonthly andseasonalchanges inbirth weight were more obvious inmale than infemale fetusesâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 1) è¥¿è—æ ·æœ¬ä¸­ï¼Œç”·æ€§èƒå„¿å‡ºç”Ÿä½“é‡çš„æœˆåº¦å’Œå­£èŠ‚å˜åŒ–è¾ƒå¥³æ€§æ›´ä¸ºæ˜æ˜¾ã€‚
â€œthemale fetuses were more sensitive tohypoxia than the female fetuses.â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) ç”·æ€§èƒå„¿æ¯”å¥³æ€§èƒå„¿å¯¹ç¼ºæ°§æ›´æ•æ„Ÿã€‚
â€œEvidently, thenative Tibetan male fetuses have higher fitness under hypoxia than theHan Chinese male fetuses.â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) å¯è§ï¼Œè—æ—ç”·èƒåœ¨ç¼ºæ°§æ¡ä»¶ä¸‹çš„é€‚åº”åº¦é«˜äºæ±‰æ—ç”·èƒã€‚
â€œintegrating thesex-biased patterns existingintheanalysis oftheuniparental gene pool, phenome, and gene expression to update the population history inthe Tibetan Plateauâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) æ•´åˆå•äº²åŸºå› åº“ã€è¡¨å‹å’ŒåŸºå› è¡¨è¾¾åˆ†æä¸­å­˜åœ¨çš„è¿™äº›æ€§åˆ«åè§æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œä»¥æ›´æ–°é’è—é«˜åŸçš„äººå£å†å²
â€œheadaptive introgression ofthe Denisovan-like EPAS1 gene which contributes toreproductive fitness (Heetal.,2023a; Yue et al.,2023) occurred during theUpper Paleolithic (Zhang etal.,2021).â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) æœ‰åŠ©äºç”Ÿæ®–å¥åº·çš„ç±»ä¸¹å°¼ç´¢ç“¦äºº EPAS1 åŸºå› çš„é€‚åº”æ€§æ¸—å…¥å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨æ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ™šæœŸï¼ˆZhang et al.,2021ï¼‰ã€‚
â€œncient hunter-gatherers living inhigh altitudes, such as males with Ychromosome haplogroup D-M174, harbored theadaptive EPAS1 haplotype.â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) ç”Ÿæ´»åœ¨é«˜æµ·æ‹”åœ°åŒºçš„å¤ä»£ç‹©çŒé‡‡é›†è€…ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å…·æœ‰ Y æŸ“è‰²ä½“å•å€ç¾¤ D-M174 çš„ç”·æ€§ï¼Œæ‹¥æœ‰é€‚åº”æ€§ EPAS1 å•å€å‹ã€‚
â€œAfter admixture with the Neolithic farmers and herders from low altitudes, theadmixed population migrated across theTibetan Plateau.â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) ä¸æ–°çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£ä½æµ·æ‹”åœ°åŒºçš„å†œç‰§æ°‘æ··åˆåï¼Œè¿™äº›æ··æ‚äººå£è·¨è¶Šé’è—é«˜åŸè¿å¾™ã€‚
â€œThe stronger selective pressure duetohypoxia onmale fetuses likely maintained the docents with Upper Paleolithic lineage such ashaplogroup D-M174, asthey might have high-altitude adaptative EPAS1 gene.â€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) ç”·æ€§èƒå„¿å› ç¼ºæ°§è€Œäº§ç”Ÿçš„æ›´å¼ºçš„é€‰æ‹©å‹åŠ›å¯èƒ½ä¿ç•™äº†æ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ™šæœŸè°±ç³»ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å•å€ç¾¤D-M174ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä»–ä»¬å¯èƒ½å…·æœ‰é«˜æµ·æ‹”é€‚åº”EPAS1åŸºå› ã€‚
â€œIncontrast, theselection of hypoxia was relatively weak infemale fetuses, which might allow theexpansion ofNeolithic maternal lineages such as haplogroups M9a1a1c1b1a andA11a1a from thelowlandsâ€ (Peng å’Œ Zhang, p. 2) ç›¸æ¯”ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼Œå¥³æ€§èƒå„¿çš„ç¼ºæ°§é€‰æ‹©ç›¸å¯¹è¾ƒå¼±ï¼Œè¿™å¯èƒ½å…è®¸æ–°çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£æ¯ç³»è°±ç³»çš„æ‰©å±•ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ¥è‡ªä½åœ°çš„å•å€ç¾¤M9a1a1c1b1aå’ŒA11a1aã€‚

åœ¨è¿‡å»çš„åå¹´ä¸­ï¼Œé•¿è¯»é•¿ DNA æµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯å·²æˆä¸ºåŸºå› ç»„å­¦é¢†åŸŸçš„å¼ºå¤§å‚ä¸è€…ã€‚è¿™äº›å¹³å°èƒ½å¤Ÿç”Ÿæˆé•¿åº¦ä¸ºæ•°ä¸‡è‡³æ•°åƒç¢±åŸºçš„è¯»æ•°ï¼Œå…¶å‡†ç¡®åº¦æ¥è¿‘çŸ­è¯»é•¿æµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯ï¼Œå·²è¯æ˜å®ƒä»¬æœ‰èƒ½åŠ›è§£å†³äººç±»åŸºå› ç»„ä¸­ä¸€äº›æœ€å…·æŒ‘æˆ˜æ€§çš„åŒºåŸŸï¼Œæ£€æµ‹ä»¥å‰æ— æ³•è®¿é—®çš„ç»“æ„å˜å¼‚å¹¶äº§ç”Ÿæ•´ä¸ªæŸ“è‰²ä½“çš„ä¸€äº›ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªç«¯ç²’åˆ°ç«¯ç²’ç»„è£…ã€‚é•¿è¯»é•¿æµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯å¾ˆå¿«å°†å…è®¸äºŒå€ä½“åŸºå› ç»„çš„å¸¸è§„ç»„è£…ï¼Œè¿™å°†é€šè¿‡æ­ç¤ºäººç±»é—ä¼ å˜å¼‚çš„å…¨è°±ã€è§£å†³ä¸€äº›ç¼ºå¤±çš„é—ä¼ æ€§å¹¶å¯¼è‡´æ–°çš„ç–¾ç—…æœºåˆ¶çš„å‘ç°æ¥å½»åº•æ”¹å˜åŸºå› ç»„å­¦ã€‚

åŸºå› ç»„ä¸­è¿™äº›éš¾ä»¥æ¥è¿‘çš„éƒ¨åˆ†åŒ…æ‹¬ç€ä¸ç²’ã€ç«¯ç²’å’Œè¿‘ç«¯ç€ä¸ç²’åŸºå› ç»„åŒºåŸŸï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å¤§é‡ä¸²è”é‡å¤åºåˆ—å ä¸»å¯¼åœ°ä½ï¼Œä»¥åŠæ˜ å°„åˆ°å¤§ç‰‡æ®µé‡å¤çš„åŸºå› ç»„ï¼ˆå’Œç›¸å…³åŸºå› ï¼‰çš„ 5%ï¼›è®½åˆºçš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™äº›åŒºåŸŸåœ¨ç§ç³»å’Œä½“ç»†èƒä¸­ä¹Ÿç»å†äº†ä¸€äº›æœ€é«˜çš„çªå˜ç‡ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åŸºå› ç»„ä¸­ä¸€äº›æœ€å¯å˜çš„åŒºåŸŸé€šå¸¸æœªè¢«å……åˆ†ç ”ç©¶ã€‚è¿™äº›é™åˆ¶ä½¿å¾—éœ€è¦å¼€å‘èƒ½å¤Ÿè§£æåŸºå› ç»„ä¸­è¿™äº›æ›´å¤æ‚å’ŒåŠ¨æ€åŒºåŸŸçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

æœ‰è®¸å¤šçš„é€šè¿‡çŸ­è¯»é•¿æ¥åˆæˆé•¿åºåˆ—çš„åŠæ³•ï¼šä¾‹å¦‚é«˜é€šé‡æŸ“è‰²ä½“æ„è±¡æ•è·æŠ€æœ¯(High-throughput chromosome conformation capture,Hi-C)ç­‰ã€‚å°½ç®¡ Hi-C åœ¨ç»“æ„å˜å¼‚æ£€æµ‹æ–¹é¢ä¼˜äºç®€å•çš„çŸ­è¯»é•¿æµ‹åºæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä½†ç»„è£…çš„åŸºæœ¬å•ä½ä»ç„¶æ˜¯çŸ­è¯»é•¿ï¼Œè¿™æå¤§åœ°é™åˆ¶äº†æ£€æµ‹å’Œå®Œå…¨ç»„è£…ç»“æ„å˜å¼‚åŒºåŸŸçš„èƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œç‰¹åˆ«æ˜¯åœ¨è¾ƒå¤§çš„é‡å¤ä¸­ã€‚å¯¹äºè¿™äº›åº”ç”¨ï¼Œé“¾æ¥è¯»é•¿ã€åˆæˆé•¿è¯»é•¿å’Œ Hi-C æµ‹åºæ–¹æ³•é€šå¸¸ä¸å¦‚ä¸¥æ ¼çš„é•¿è¯»é•¿æµ‹åºæ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Pacific Biosciencesæµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯ï¼ˆSMRT,PacBioï¼‰
Oxford Nanopore Technologiesç‰›æ´¥çº³ç±³å­”æµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯ (ONT)

PacBio å’Œ ONT æµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯æ‰€äº§ç”Ÿçš„è¯»æ•°éƒ½å¯ä»¥è½»æ¾ç©¿è¶Šäººç±»åŸºå› ç»„ä¸­æœ€é‡å¤çš„åŒºåŸŸï¼Œä½†å…¶åŒ–å­¦å’Œåºåˆ—æ£€æµ‹æ–¹æ³•çš„æ½œåœ¨å·®å¼‚ä¼šå½±å“å®ƒä»¬çš„è¯»æ•°é•¿åº¦ã€ç¢±åŸºå‡†ç¡®æ€§å’Œé€šé‡ã€‚

ç•¥

è¿™äº›è¿›å±•å°†æå¤§åœ°æé«˜æˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹äººç±»é—ä¼ æ€§ã€ç§ç¾¤å¤šæ ·æ€§ã€çªå˜è¿‡ç¨‹ä»¥åŠç–¾ç—…é—ä¼ åŸºç¡€çš„ç†è§£ã€‚å€¼å¾—æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œé•¿è¯»é•¿ DNA æµ‹åºæŠ€æœ¯çš„é‡‡ç”¨ä¹Ÿå°†æ”¹å˜æˆ‘ä»¬å‘ç°å’Œè®°å½•äººç±»å˜å¼‚çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚
å˜å¼‚çš„å‘ç°ä¸æ˜¯é€šè¿‡ç®€å•åœ°å°†è¯»æ•°ä¸å•ä¸ªå‚è€ƒåŸºå› ç»„è¿›è¡Œæ¯”å¯¹å¹¶æ¨æ–­é—ä¼ å·®å¼‚ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯é€šè¿‡æµ‹åºå’Œç»„è£…å®Œæ•´çš„å•å€å‹ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å¤æ‚çš„é—ä¼ å˜å¼‚å·²å®Œå…¨åºåˆ—è§£æã€‚æ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„æ­¥éª¤å¯èƒ½æ¶‰åŠä½¿ç”¨æ–°æ ‡å‡†ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ Variant Graph Toolkit159ï¼‰å¼€å‘åŸºäºå›¾å½¢çš„å‚è€ƒåŸºå› ç»„ã€‚åŠŸèƒ½æ•°æ®å°†å åŠ åœ¨è¿™äº›å®Œæ•´çš„åŸºå› ç»„ä¸Šï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬æœ€ç»ˆåœ¨ç»†èƒå’Œå‘è‚²æ°´å¹³ä¸Šå‘ç”Ÿçš„è¡¨è§‚é—ä¼ å’Œè½¬å½•ç»„å·®å¼‚ã€‚ä¸çŸ­è¯»é•¿æµ‹åºç›¸æ¯”ï¼Œå•åˆ†å­é•¿è¯»é•¿æµ‹åºæä¾›äº†ä¸°å¯Œçš„é™„åŠ ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œæœ‰åŠ©äºæ›´å…¨é¢åœ°äº†è§£é—ä¼ ã€è¡¨è§‚é—ä¼ å’Œè½¬å½•ç»„å˜å¼‚åŠå…¶ä¸äººç±»è¡¨å‹çš„å…³ç³»ã€‚

item.title: æ‘˜è¦
item.description:
#è½¯ä»¶ #è½¯ä»¶
Mitochondrial origin of the matrilocal Mosuo people in China

â€œmatrilocal population in Chinaâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) æ¯ç³»ç¤¾ä¼šç¾¤ä½“â€œThe origins of the population and their matrilocal tradition remain unknown.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) äººå£çš„èµ·æºåŠå…¶æ¯ç³»ä¼ ç»Ÿä»ç„¶æœªçŸ¥ã€‚
â€œwomen remain with their families after marriageâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) å¦‡å¥³å©šåä»ä¸å®¶äººåœ¨ä¸€èµ·â€œHowever, the haplotype diversity of this population is not lower than the neighboring patrilocal populations, indicating that the Mosuo started practicing matrilocality at least after the Paleolithic Age.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) ä½†è¯¥äººç¾¤çš„å•å€å‹å¤šæ ·æ€§å¹¶ä¸ä½äºé‚»è¿‘çš„çˆ¶ç³»ç¤¾ä¼šäººç¾¤ï¼Œè¡¨æ˜æ‘©æ¢­äººï¼ˆMosuoï¼‰è‡³å°‘åœ¨æ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£ä¹‹åå°±å¼€å§‹å®è¡Œæ¯ç³»ç”Ÿæ´»ã€‚
â€œA previous haplogroup frequency clustering study indicated that the Mosuo are closest to the Naxi people, but the network analysis of individual sequence haplotypes presented herein shows that most Mosuo lineages cluster with Pumi lineages.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) å…ˆå‰çš„å•å€ç¾¤é¢‘ç‡èšç±»ç ”ç©¶è¡¨æ˜æ‘©æ¢­äººä¸çº³è¥¿äººæœ€æ¥è¿‘ï¼Œä½†æœ¬æ–‡æå‡ºçš„ä¸ªä½“åºåˆ—å•å€å‹çš„ç½‘ç»œåˆ†æè¡¨æ˜å¤§å¤šæ•°æ‘©æ¢­äººè°±ç³»ä¸æ™®ç±³äººè°±ç³»èšç±»ã€‚â€œthey started to practice matrilocality several thousand years ago.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) ä»–ä»¬åœ¨å‡ åƒå¹´å‰å°±å¼€å§‹å®è¡Œæ¯å±…åˆ¶ã€‚

â€œThe Mosuo, the last living matrilocal population in Mainland China (Gottner-Abendroth 1999), have a population of around 53,000 (2010 census), mostly distributed around Lugu Lake, on the border of Yunnan and Sichuan provincesâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) æ‘©æ¢­äººæ˜¯ä¸­å›½å¤§é™†æœ€åçš„æ¯ç³»äººå£ï¼ˆGottner-Abendroth 1999ï¼‰ï¼Œäººå£çº¦ 53,000 äººï¼ˆ2010 å¹´äººå£æ™®æŸ¥ï¼‰ï¼Œä¸»è¦åˆ†å¸ƒåœ¨äº‘å—çœå’Œå››å·çœäº¤ç•Œçš„æ³¸æ²½æ¹–å‘¨è¾¹ã€‚
â€œmost present-day populations have been practicing patrilocality (i.e. a practice in which females are exchanged frequently among populations) for many years, maternal lineages form very complex networks, making it difficult to trace the matrilineal history of these populations.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) å½“ä»Šå¤§å¤šæ•°äººå£å¤šå¹´æ¥ä¸€ç›´å®è¡Œçˆ¶ç³»åˆ¶ï¼ˆå³å¥³æ€§åœ¨äººå£ä¹‹é—´é¢‘ç¹äº¤æ¢çš„åšæ³•ï¼‰ï¼Œæ¯ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿå½¢æˆéå¸¸å¤æ‚çš„ç½‘ç»œï¼Œä½¿å¾—è¿½è¸ªè¿™äº›äººå£çš„æ¯ç³»å†å²å˜å¾—å›°éš¾ã€‚
â€œThe present language of the Mosuo belongs to TangutQiang branch of the Sino-Tibetan language family. Ethnographic studies suggest that the Mosuo were believed to be descendants of the ancient Qiang tribes.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 13) æ‘©æ¢­äººç°ç”¨çš„è¯­è¨€å±æ±‰è—è¯­ç³»è¥¿å¤ç¾Œè¯­æ—ã€‚æ°‘æ—å¿—ç ”ç©¶è¡¨æ˜ï¼Œæ‘©æ¢­äººè¢«è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯å¤ä»£ç¾Œæ—éƒ¨è½çš„åè£”ã€‚
â€œThey originally lived in Northwest China, and some migrated to Southwest China about 2700 years ago, where they diversified into several branches. Among these branches, the Tangut-Qiang is most similar to the ancient Qiangâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 14) ä»–ä»¬æœ€åˆç”Ÿæ´»åœ¨ä¸­å›½è¥¿åŒ—åœ°åŒºï¼Œå¤§çº¦2700å¹´å‰ï¼Œä¸€äº›äººè¿å¾™åˆ°ä¸­å›½è¥¿å—åœ°åŒºï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨é‚£é‡Œåˆ†åŒ–æˆå¤šä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ã€‚åœ¨è¿™äº›æ”¯ç³»ä¸­ï¼Œè¥¿å¤ç¾Œè¯­ä¸å¤ç¾Œè¯­æœ€ä¸ºç›¸ä¼¼ã€‚
â€œA study of Y-STR polymorphisms among five Chinese minorities shows that the Tibetan and Mosuo peoples are closest in paternal lineage (Yang et al. 2004).â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 14) å¯¹ä¸­å›½äº”ä¸ªå°‘æ•°æ°‘æ—çš„ Y-STR å¤šæ€æ€§ç ”ç©¶è¡¨æ˜ï¼Œè—æ—å’Œæ‘©æ¢­äººçš„çˆ¶ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿæœ€æ¥è¿‘ï¼ˆYang et al. 2004ï¼‰ã€‚
â€œprevious study of the Mosuo people suggests that they have various paternal origins, and therefore cannot identify a definitive source of genetic originâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 14) å…ˆå‰å¯¹æ‘©æ¢­äººçš„ç ”ç©¶è¡¨æ˜ï¼Œä»–ä»¬æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„çˆ¶ç³»èµ·æºï¼Œå› æ­¤æ— æ³•ç¡®å®šé—ä¼ èµ·æºçš„æ˜ç¡®æ¥æºã€‚



â€œThe maternal lineages of the Mosuo bear the strongest resemblance with those found in Naxi (Wen et al. 2004b).â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 14) æ‘©æ¢­äººçš„æ¯ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿä¸çº³è¥¿æ—çš„æ¯ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿæœ€ä¸ºç›¸ä¼¼ï¼ˆWen et al. 2004bï¼‰ã€‚

â€œPeripheral blood samples from 47 Mosuo individuals, 14 Naxi individuals, and 18 Pumi individuals from various villages were collected for this study, with an approval from the Ethics Committee of the Fudan School of Life Sciences.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 14) æœ¬ç ”ç©¶ç»å¤æ—¦å¤§å­¦ç”Ÿå‘½ç§‘å­¦å­¦é™¢ä¼¦ç†å§”å‘˜ä¼šæ‰¹å‡†ï¼Œé‡‡é›†äº†æ¥è‡ªä¸åŒæ‘åº„çš„47åæ‘©æ¢­äººã€14åçº³è¥¿æ—å’Œ18åæ™®ç±³æ—äººçš„å¤–å‘¨è¡€æ ·æœ¬ã€‚

â€œAll the HVS-1 sequences of the Mosuo people in this study are included in GenBank (HM215521-67).â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 15) æœ¬ç ”ç©¶ä¸­æ‘©æ¢­äººçš„æ‰€æœ‰HVS-1åºåˆ—å‡æ”¶å½•åœ¨GenBankä¸­ï¼ˆHM215521-67ï¼‰ã€‚

â€œHaplotype diversity was calculated using Arlequin software (Version 3.11â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 15) ä½¿ç”¨Arlequinè½¯ä»¶ï¼ˆç‰ˆæœ¬3.11ï¼‰è®¡ç®—å•å€å‹å¤šæ ·æ€§ã€‚
#è½¯ä»¶
â€œNetworks of mtDNA HVS-1 motifs were constructed by the median-joining method (Bandelt et al. 1999) using Network version 4.5.1.0â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 15) mtDNA HVS-1 åŸºåºçš„ç½‘ç»œæ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ Network version4.5.1.0 é€šè¿‡ä¸­å€¼è¿æ¥æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆBandelt ç­‰äººï¼Œ1999ï¼‰æ„å»ºçš„ã€‚
#è½¯ä»¶

â€œHowever, we found that the mtDNA HVS-1 haplotype diversity of Mosuo (0.9843) is not always lower than those of surrounding patriarchal populations, but even higher than those of the Naxi and Pumiâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 15) ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å‘ç°æ‘©æ¢­äººçš„mtDNA HVS-1å•å€å‹å¤šæ ·æ€§ï¼ˆ0.9843ï¼‰å¹¶ä¸æ€»æ˜¯ä½äºå‘¨è¾¹çˆ¶ç³»äººç¾¤ï¼Œç”šè‡³é«˜äºçº³è¥¿æ—å’Œæ™®ç±³æ—ã€‚â€œMosuo are considered intermediate among comparative populationâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 15) æ‘©æ¢­äººè¢«è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯ç›¸å¯¹äººå£ä¸­çš„ä¸­é—´äººã€‚
â€œThere may be three mechanisms for a matrilocal population that would result in a population not exhibiting low mtDNA diversity: large population size, frequent admixture with other populations, and short matrilocality historyâ€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 15) æ¯ç³»ç§ç¾¤å¯èƒ½å­˜åœ¨ä¸‰ç§æœºåˆ¶å¯¼è‡´ç§ç¾¤ä¸è¡¨ç°å‡ºä½çº¿ç²’ä½“DNAå¤šæ ·æ€§ã€‚

ç§ç¾¤è§„æ¨¡å¤§
ä¸å…¶ä»–ç§ç¾¤é¢‘ç¹æ··åˆ
æ¯ç³»å†å²çŸ­ã€‚
â€œThe last possible explanation for this pattern is that the Mosuo might have switched from patrilocality to matrilocality very recently, and that their matrilocal society has not yet left visible effects on their genetic structure.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 16) å¯¹äºè¿™ç§æ¨¡å¼çš„æœ€åä¸€ç§å¯èƒ½çš„è§£é‡Šæ˜¯ï¼Œæ‘©æ¢­äººå¯èƒ½æœ€è¿‘æ‰ä»çˆ¶ç³»è½¬å˜ä¸ºæ¯ç³»ï¼Œè€Œä¸”ä»–ä»¬çš„æ¯ç³»ç¤¾ä¼šå°šæœªå¯¹å…¶é—ä¼ ç»“æ„äº§ç”Ÿæ˜æ˜¾çš„å½±å“ã€‚
â€œindicating that the Mosuo may not be a population that has existed since Paleolithic Age, as previously suggested.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 16) è¡¨æ˜æ‘©æ¢­äººå¯èƒ½ä¸åƒä¹‹å‰æ‰€è¯´çš„é‚£æ ·æ˜¯è‡ªæ—§çŸ³å™¨æ—¶ä»£ä»¥æ¥å°±å­˜åœ¨çš„äººç¾¤ã€‚
â€œThe six major mtDNA haplogroups (B4, B5a, C, D, D5a, and F1b) encompass over 80% of the Mosuo samples.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 17) ==å…­ä¸ªä¸»è¦ mtDNA å•å€ç¾¤ï¼ˆB4ã€B5aã€Cã€Dã€D5a å’Œ F1bï¼‰æ¶µç›–äº†è¶…è¿‡ 80% çš„æ‘©æ¢­æ ·æœ¬==ã€‚
â€œMost populations are scattered all over the network, indicating high diversity in maternal lineages as well as an ancient common ancestors for Sino-Tibetan populations.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 17) å¤§å¤šæ•°äººç¾¤åˆ†æ•£åœ¨æ•´ä¸ªç½‘ç»œä¸­ï¼Œè¿™è¡¨æ˜æ¯ç³»è°±ç³»å…·æœ‰é«˜åº¦å¤šæ ·æ€§ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æ±‰è—äººç¾¤æ‹¥æœ‰å¤è€çš„å…±åŒç¥–å…ˆã€‚
â€œIf the Mosuo (M) was closest to the Naxi (X), as we previously showed, or shared or connected haplotypes are expected between the two populations in Figure 2, we would expect them to share a recent common ancestor. However, no such relationship was seen in the network, strongly arguing against the assumption that the Mosuo and Naxi share a recent common ancestor in their maternal lineages.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 17) å¦‚æœæ‘©æ¢­äºº (M) æœ€æ¥è¿‘çº³è¥¿äºº (X)ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹‹å‰æ‰€å±•ç¤ºçš„ï¼Œæˆ–è€…å›¾ 2 ä¸­çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªç¾¤ä½“ä¹‹é—´é¢„è®¡å­˜åœ¨å…±äº«æˆ–ç›¸å…³çš„å•å€å‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬é¢„è®¡ä»–ä»¬æ‹¥æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæœ€è¿‘çš„å…±åŒç¥–å…ˆã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œåœ¨ç½‘ç»œä¸­å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰çœ‹åˆ°è¿™æ ·çš„å…³ç³»ï¼Œå¼ºçƒˆåå¯¹æ‘©æ¢­äººå’Œçº³è¥¿äººåœ¨æ¯ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿä¸Šæ‹¥æœ‰æœ€è¿‘å…±åŒç¥–å…ˆçš„å‡è®¾ã€‚



â€œThis provides strong evidence for the affinity between the Mosuo and Pumi in the maternal lineages.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 17) è¿™ä¸ºæ‘©æ¢­äººå’Œæ™®ç±³äººåœ¨æ¯ç³»è¡€ç»Ÿä¸Šçš„äº²ç¼˜å…³ç³»æä¾›äº†æœ‰åŠ›çš„è¯æ®ã€‚

â€œThis indicates that simply comparing haplogroup frequencies among populations is not sufficient in mtDNA data analyses and sometime even results in large bias. A network analysis can offer more details and higher resolution about population relationships.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 18) è¿™è¡¨æ˜ï¼Œåœ¨çº¿ç²’ä½“DNAæ•°æ®åˆ†æä¸­ï¼Œç®€å•åœ°æ¯”è¾ƒäººç¾¤ä¹‹é—´çš„å•å€ç¾¤é¢‘ç‡æ˜¯ä¸å¤Ÿçš„ï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶ç”šè‡³ä¼šå¯¼è‡´è¾ƒå¤§çš„åå·®ã€‚ç½‘ç»œåˆ†æå¯ä»¥æä¾›æœ‰å…³äººå£å…³ç³»çš„æ›´å¤šç»†èŠ‚å’Œæ›´é«˜çš„åˆ†è¾¨ç‡ã€‚
â€œThe Mosuo are not really isolated from the Pumi or the Lolo, but rather they are quite possibly a part of Pumi. Therefore, the most probable explanation is that Mosuo started matrilocality not long ago, and a possible reason for abandoning patrilocality is the frequent mercantile travels of their men.â€ (Lu ç­‰, 2012, p. 18) æ‘©æ¢­äººå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯çœŸæ­£ä¸æ™®ç±³æ—æˆ–å½æ—éš”ç»ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å¾ˆå¯èƒ½æ˜¯æ™®ç±³æ—çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæœ€å¯èƒ½çš„è§£é‡Šæ˜¯ï¼Œæ‘©æ¢­äººä¸ä¹…å‰å°±å¼€å§‹äº†æ¯ç³»åˆ¶ï¼Œè€Œæ”¾å¼ƒçˆ¶ç³»ç¤¾ä¼šçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå¯èƒ½åŸå› æ˜¯ä»–ä»¬çš„ç”·äººé¢‘ç¹çš„å¾€æ¥æ—…è¡Œã€‚

A globally diverse reference alignment and panel for imputation of mitochondrial DNA variants


é€šè¿‡åŸºå› åˆ†å‹å¾®é˜µåˆ—æˆ–ä»…å¯¹åŸºå› ç»„é«˜å˜åŒºè¿›è¡Œæµ‹åºæ¥é‰´å®šçº¿ç²’ä½“ DNA (mtDNA) çš„å˜å¼‚å¯èƒ½ä¸è¶³ä»¥å¯é åœ°å°†çº¿ç²’ä½“åŸºå› ç»„åˆ†é…ç»™ç³»ç»Ÿå‘è‚²è°±ç³»æˆ–å•å€ç¾¤ã€‚è¿™ç§åˆ†è¾¨ç‡çš„ç¼ºä¹å¯èƒ½ä¼šé™åˆ¶å¯¹å¤§é‡ç°æœ‰ mtDNA æ•°æ®çš„åŠŸèƒ½å’Œä¸´åºŠè§£é‡Šã€‚ä¸ºäº†è§£å†³è¿™ä¸€é™åˆ¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¼€å‘å¹¶è¯„ä¼°äº†å®Œæ•´ mtDNA åºåˆ—çš„å¤§å‹ã€ç²¾å¿ƒç­–åˆ’çš„å‚è€ƒæ¯”å¯¹ï¼Œä½œä¸ºä¼°ç®—ç¼ºå¤± mtDNA å•æ ¸è‹·é…¸å˜å¼‚ (mtSNV) çš„ç®¡é“çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å‚è€ƒå¯¹é½å’Œç®¡é“ç§°ä¸º MitoImputeã€‚

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹ä» GenBank ä¸‹è½½çš„ 36,960 ä¸ªå®Œæ•´äººç±»çº¿ç²’ä½“åŸºå› ç»„çš„åºåˆ—è¿›è¡Œäº†æ¯”å¯¹ï¼Œå¹¶è¿›è¡Œäº†è¿‡æ»¤å’Œè´¨é‡æ§åˆ¶ã€‚è¿™äº›åºåˆ—è¢«é‡æ–°æ ¼å¼åŒ–ä»¥ç”¨äºæ’è¡¥è½¯ä»¶ IMPUTE2ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡æµ‹é‡ 1000 ä¸ªåŸºå› ç»„è®¡åˆ’å’Œé˜¿å°”èŒ¨æµ·é»˜ç—…ç¥ç»å½±åƒè®¡åˆ’ (ADNI) æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„å•å€ç¾¤å’ŒåŸºå› å‹ä¸€è‡´æ€§æ¥è¯„ä¼° MitoImpute çš„æ’è¡¥å‡†ç¡®æ€§ã€‚ 1000 ä¸ªåŸºå› ç»„æ ·æœ¬ä¸­å•å€ç¾¤åˆ†é…çš„å¹³å‡æ”¹å–„ç‡ä¸º 42.7%ï¼ˆé©¬ä¿®ç›¸å…³ç³»æ•° = 0.64ï¼‰ã€‚åœ¨ ADNI é˜Ÿåˆ—ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¼°ç®—äº†ç¼ºå¤±çš„å•æ ¸è‹·é…¸å˜å¼‚ã€‚

è¿™äº›ç»“æœè¡¨æ˜ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„å‚è€ƒæ¯”å¯¹å’Œé¢æ¿å¯ç”¨äºä¼°ç®—ä½¿ç”¨å¾®é˜µåˆ—è·å¾—çš„ç°æœ‰æ•°æ®ä¸­ç¼ºå¤±çš„ mtSNVï¼Œä»è€Œæ‰©å¤§ mtDNA çš„åŠŸèƒ½å’Œä¸´åºŠç ”ç©¶èŒƒå›´ã€‚è¿™ç§æ”¹è¿›å¯èƒ½åœ¨éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»æ‹›å‹Ÿå‚ä¸è€…å¹¶ä½¿ç”¨ä¸åŒæ–¹æ³•è·å¾— mtDNA æ•°æ®çš„ç ”ç©¶ä¸­ç‰¹åˆ«æœ‰ç”¨ï¼Œä»è€Œèƒ½å¤Ÿæ›´å¥½åœ°å°†ä½¿ç”¨ä¸å¤ªå‡†ç¡®çš„æ–¹æ³•æ”¶é›†çš„æ—©æœŸæ•°æ®ä¸è¾ƒæ–°çš„åºåˆ—æ•°æ®æ•´åˆèµ·æ¥ã€‚

â€œPartial mtSNV data obtained using such arrays may be insufficient for reliable haplotype assignment of mitochondrial genomes.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 2) ä½¿ç”¨æ­¤ç±»é˜µåˆ—è·å¾—çš„éƒ¨åˆ† mtSNV æ•°æ®å¯èƒ½ä¸è¶³ä»¥å¯¹çº¿ç²’ä½“åŸºå› ç»„è¿›è¡Œå¯é çš„å•å€å‹åˆ†é…ã€‚
â€œIn addition, not all microarrays are designed to assay variation at the same sites in the human mitochondrial genome. Inconsistencies in the design of microarrays used in different studies can result in mtSNV datasets that are partially incompatible, making it difficult to combine them for joint analysis.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 2) æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œå¹¶éæ‰€æœ‰å¾®é˜µåˆ—éƒ½æ—¨åœ¨æ£€æµ‹äººç±»çº¿ç²’ä½“åŸºå› ç»„ä¸­ç›¸åŒä½ç‚¹çš„å˜å¼‚ã€‚ä¸åŒç ”ç©¶ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨çš„å¾®é˜µåˆ—è®¾è®¡çš„ä¸ä¸€è‡´å¯èƒ½ä¼šå¯¼è‡´ mtSNV æ•°æ®é›†éƒ¨åˆ†ä¸å…¼å®¹ï¼Œä»è€Œå¾ˆéš¾å°†å®ƒä»¬ç»„åˆèµ·æ¥è¿›è¡Œè”åˆåˆ†æã€‚
â€œAdditionally, studies as recent as 2021 have used imputation as a tool to fill in missing mtSNVs for genotypephenotype association studies , highlighting the continued importance imputation plays in biomedical research.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 2) æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œæœ€è¿‘åœ¨ 2021 å¹´çš„ç ”ç©¶å·²ä½¿ç”¨æ’è¡¥ä½œä¸ºå·¥å…·æ¥å¡«è¡¥åŸºå› å‹è¡¨å‹å…³è”ç ”ç©¶ä¸­ç¼ºå¤±çš„ mtSNV [1]ï¼Œè¿™çªæ˜¾äº†æ’è¡¥åœ¨ç”Ÿç‰©åŒ»å­¦ç ”ç©¶ä¸­æŒç»­å‘æŒ¥çš„é‡è¦ä½œç”¨ã€‚
â€œAccurate estimation of these probabilities has two fundamental requirements: (1) An accurate multiple sequence alignment (MSA) of genome sequences; and (2) A reference panel of genome sequences that is representative of the population being investigated.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 2) å‡†ç¡®ä¼°è®¡è¿™äº›æ¦‚ç‡æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªåŸºæœ¬è¦æ±‚ï¼š

åŸºå› ç»„åºåˆ—çš„å‡†ç¡®å¤šåºåˆ—æ¯”å¯¹ï¼ˆMSAï¼‰
æœ‰ä»£è¡¨çš„ç ”ç©¶äººç¾¤çš„å‚è€ƒåŸºå› ç»„åºåˆ—
â€œData that is unrepresentative because it was obtained from an inappropriate population, can cause imputation to be biased and inaccurateâ€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 2) ç”±äºæ•°æ®æ˜¯ä»ä¸é€‚å½“çš„äººç¾¤ä¸­è·å¾—çš„ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä¸å…·æœ‰ä»£è¡¨æ€§ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šå¯¼è‡´ä¼°ç®—å‡ºç°åå·®å’Œä¸å‡†ç¡®[2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7]ã€‚
â€œAdditional bias and inaccuracy may arise during construction of MSAs, which entails inserting alignment gaps (â€˜â€“â€™) between some of the nucleotides in some of the sequences being alignedâ€”doing so accurately is a nontrivial challengeâ€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 2) åœ¨æ„å»º MSA è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å¯èƒ½ä¼šå‡ºç°é¢å¤–çš„åå·®å’Œä¸å‡†ç¡®æ€§ï¼Œè¿™éœ€è¦åœ¨ä¸€äº›æ­£åœ¨æ¯”å¯¹çš„åºåˆ—ä¸­çš„ä¸€äº›æ ¸è‹·é…¸ä¹‹é—´æ’å…¥æ¯”å¯¹é—´éš™ï¼ˆâ€œ-â€ï¼‰â€”â€”å‡†ç¡®åœ°åšåˆ°è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸å°çš„æŒ‘æˆ˜ã€‚
â€œreference panels containing high-quality complete data from as many globally diverse populations is required.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 3) éœ€è¦åŒ…å«æ¥è‡ªå°½å¯èƒ½å¤šçš„å…¨çƒä¸åŒäººç¾¤çš„é«˜è´¨é‡å®Œæ•´æ•°æ®çš„å‚è€ƒé¢æ¿ã€‚
â€œpreliminary data reformatting, identification and curation of suitable reference data panels, and standardisation of high-quality multisequence alignments.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 3) å¿…é¡»å®ç°çš„åŸºç¡€æ˜¯ï¼š

åˆæ­¥æ•°æ®é‡æ–°æ ¼å¼åŒ–
åˆé€‚å‚è€ƒæ•°æ®ç»„çš„è¯†åˆ«å’Œç®¡ç†
é«˜è´¨é‡å¤šåºåˆ—æ¯”å¯¹çš„æ ‡å‡†åŒ–


â€œIMPUTE2 information score of â‰¤ 0.3.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 5)ï¼š(McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 5) ä¿¡æ¯è¯„åˆ†â‰¤0.3çš„ä½ç‚¹åœ¨é—ä¼ å­¦æ•°æ®åˆ†æä¸­ï¼Œä¿¡æ¯è¯„åˆ†ï¼ˆInfo Score æˆ– IMPUTE2ä¿¡æ¯è¯„åˆ†ï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç”¨æ¥è¡¡é‡åŸºå› å‹æ’è¡¥è´¨é‡çš„æŒ‡æ ‡ã€‚IMPUTE2è½¯ä»¶åœ¨è¿›è¡ŒåŸºå› å‹æ’è¡¥åä¼šè¾“å‡ºè¿™ä¸€è¯„åˆ†ï¼Œè¯¥è¯„åˆ†èŒƒå›´é€šå¸¸åœ¨0åˆ°1ä¹‹é—´ã€‚è¯„åˆ†è¶Šæ¥è¿‘1ï¼Œè¡¨æ˜æ’è¡¥çš„ç½®ä¿¡åº¦è¶Šé«˜ï¼Œå³è¯¥ä½ç‚¹çš„æ’è¡¥ç»“æœè¶Šå¯é ã€‚ç›¸åï¼Œè¯„åˆ†è¾ƒä½ï¼ˆå¦‚â‰¤0.3ï¼‰çš„ä½ç‚¹è¡¨æ˜æ’è¡¥çš„ä¸ç¡®å®šæ€§è¾ƒé«˜ï¼Œå› æ­¤åœ¨æŸäº›ç ”ç©¶ä¸­å¯èƒ½ä¼šé€‰æ‹©ç§»é™¤è¿™äº›è´¨é‡è¾ƒä½çš„æ’è¡¥ç»“æœã€‚å…·ä½“è®¡ç®—æ–¹æ³•æ¶‰åŠå¯¹æ¯ä¸ªæ’è¡¥ä½ç‚¹çš„ä¼°è®¡ç­‰ä½åŸºå› é¢‘ç‡çš„ç½®ä¿¡åº¦è¿›è¡Œè¯„ä¼°ã€‚åœ¨ IMPUTE2ä¸­ï¼Œè¿™é€šå¸¸é€šè¿‡å¯¹æ¯”æ’è¡¥å¾—åˆ°çš„ç­‰ä½åŸºå› é¢‘ç‡çš„é¢„æµ‹åˆ†å¸ƒä¸å®é™…è§‚å¯Ÿå€¼æ¥è¿›è¡Œã€‚
â€œHaploGrep2 has the advantage of covering the full scope of the PhyloTree haplogroup nomenclatureâ€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 5) HaploGrep2 çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿åœ¨äºæ¶µç›–äº† PhyloTree å•å€ç¾¤å‘½åæ³•çš„å…¨éƒ¨èŒƒå›´ [8]ã€‚
â€œHi-MC was developed for epidemiological research that uses high-throughput data by reducing PhyloTree nomenclature to 46 common haplogroups using a limited array of mtSNVs from which to assign haplogroups.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 5) Hi-MC æ˜¯ä¸ºæµè¡Œç—…å­¦ç ”ç©¶è€Œå¼€å‘çš„ï¼Œè¯¥ç ”ç©¶ä½¿ç”¨é«˜é€šé‡æ•°æ®ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ä½¿ç”¨æœ‰é™çš„ mtSNV é˜µåˆ—å°† PhyloTree å‘½åæ³•å‡å°‘åˆ° 46 ä¸ªå¸¸è§å•å€ç¾¤ï¼Œä»ä¸­åˆ†é…å•å€ç¾¤ [9]ã€‚


â€œPerformance testing of the MitoImpute pipeline using microarray datasets revealed a seemingly counterintuitive result; the decrease in imputation accuracy as the khap parameter increases.â€ (McInerney ç­‰, 2021, p. 11) ä½¿ç”¨å¾®é˜µåˆ—æ•°æ®é›†å¯¹ MitoImpute ç®¡é“è¿›è¡Œæ€§èƒ½æµ‹è¯•æ­ç¤ºäº†çœ‹ä¼¼è¿åç›´è§‰çš„ç»“æœï¼›éšç€ khap å‚æ•°çš„å¢åŠ ï¼Œæ’è¡¥ç²¾åº¦ä¼šé™ä½ã€‚

D-Loop-BASE is online now Central European database of mitochondrial DNA

â€œSince then, more than 1600 sequences have been included into the D-LoopBASE data stock which is now a profound basis for both frequency inquiries for expert opinions and scientific investigations into population genetic matters.â€ (Wittig ç­‰, 2003, p. 505) ä»é‚£æ—¶èµ·ï¼ŒD-LoopBASE æ•°æ®åº“å·²åŒ…å« 1600 å¤šä¸ªåºåˆ—ï¼Œè¯¥æ•°æ®åº“ç°å·²æˆä¸ºä¸“å®¶æ„è§é¢‘ç‡æŸ¥è¯¢å’Œç¾¤ä½“é—ä¼ é—®é¢˜ç§‘å­¦ç ”ç©¶çš„æ·±åšåŸºç¡€ã€‚
â€œOnline inquiries for both the frequency of individual sequences and biostatistical parameters are possible now.â€ (Wittig ç­‰, 2003, p. 505) ç°åœ¨å¯ä»¥åœ¨çº¿æŸ¥è¯¢å•ä¸ªåºåˆ—çš„é¢‘ç‡å’Œç”Ÿç‰©ç»Ÿè®¡å‚æ•°ã€‚
â€œBut individual sequences will not be published.â€ (Wittig ç­‰, 2003, p. 505) ä½†ä¸ªåˆ«åºåˆ—ä¸ä¼šå…¬å¸ƒã€‚

â€œAt present, the D-Loop-BASE database contains more than 1700 individual mtDNA sequences: 1692 sequences HV1, 1654 sequences HV2, 1628 sequences HV1 and HV2 together, 513 sequences HV3, and another 200 sequences are under preparation.â€ (Wittig ç­‰, 2003, p. 506) ç›®å‰ï¼ŒD-Loop-BASEæ•°æ®åº“åŒ…å«1700å¤šä¸ªå•ç‹¬çš„mtDNAåºåˆ—ï¼š1692ä¸ªHV1åºåˆ—ã€1654ä¸ªHV2åºåˆ—ã€1628ä¸ªHV1å’ŒHV2åºåˆ—ã€513ä¸ªHV3åºåˆ—ï¼Œå¦æœ‰200ä¸ªåºåˆ—æ­£åœ¨å‡†å¤‡ä¸­ã€‚
â€œ1610 Caucasians, i.e. 1266 from Germany, 195 from Switzerland, 102 from Austria, and 47 from 18 countries all over the world, 101 Asians (Japan) and several Africans.â€ (Wittig ç­‰, 2003, p. 506) ç™½äºº1610äººï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å¾·å›½1266äººï¼Œç‘å£«195äººï¼Œå¥¥åœ°åˆ©102äººï¼Œå…¨çƒ18ä¸ªå›½å®¶47äººï¼Œäºšæ´²äººï¼ˆæ—¥æœ¬ï¼‰101äººï¼Œéæ´²äººæ•°åã€‚
â€œThe database is hosted on a mySQL server behind the firewall of the Otto-vonGuericke-University Magdeburg. Access is realised with a special Perl script. The original data are stored and supervised in a separate database system with no online access. It is part of our security system.â€ (Wittig ç­‰, 2003, p. 507) è¯¥æ•°æ®åº“æ‰˜ç®¡åœ¨ Otto-vonGuericke-University Magdeburg é˜²ç«å¢™åé¢çš„ mySQL æœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šã€‚è®¿é—®æ˜¯é€šè¿‡ç‰¹æ®Šçš„ Perl è„šæœ¬å®ç°çš„ã€‚åŸå§‹æ•°æ®åœ¨å•ç‹¬çš„æ•°æ®åº“ç³»ç»Ÿä¸­å­˜å‚¨å’Œç›‘ç®¡ï¼Œæ— æ³•åœ¨çº¿è®¿é—®ã€‚å®ƒæ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬å®‰å…¨ç³»ç»Ÿçš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚
